concern: I’m going to get paid anyway it’s just my PI will have to pay me less. I’d get a pittance monthly and then semesterly I’d get the bulk of the money. I’d have to file taxes quarterly. The end of this week, the week before the grant is due, my PI, co-mentor and I will meet to discuss if I have enough useable preliminary data to submit in April or if I’d have to wait until August. I’ve spent so much energy working on this grant since Feb. It’s consumed my life. I’ve skipped social plans and club rehearsals. After my birthday in march I worked 13 days straight only to hear that I need more data/ my data needed to be analyzed in a different way. What’s the point of this if the only thing I get from it is a shiny bullet point on a resume? I’m feeling jaded. The other third year in my lab (with a really good project and tons of prelim data) got a borderline score so he has no idea if he will get funded or not.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! Please feel free to share whatever is on your mind or any concerns you may have. I'm here to listen and support you in a safe and non-judgmental space.
Thanks for having me. I’ve just been feeling really overwhelmed and kinda jaded with all the work I’ve been pouring into this grant, and it’s like, for what, you know?
That sounds really frustrating. It's understandable to feel overwhelmed when your hard work doesn't seem to be leading anywhere.

Yeah, it’s just been a lot, and I’m starting to question if all this stress is even worth it. Like, I’m grinding so hard, and I’m not sure what I’m really getting out of it besides maybe something to put on my resume.

It sounds like you're feeling undervalued and unfulfilled, despite all the effort you're putting into this grant. I can imagine how disheartening that must be, especially when you're giving it your all and not seeing the desired results.
Yeah, exactly, it’s like I’m running on empty and still not getting anywhere that feels meaningful. I just keep wondering if I’m wasting my time on something that might not even pan out.

It's clear that you're at a crossroads, feeling torn between the effort you're investing and the sense of purpose you're searching for. It sounds like you're questioning whether the potential outcome is worth the current emotional toll. Can you share what keeps you motivated to continue with the grant, even when it feels this way?

Honestly, I think what keeps me going is the hope that this could open some doors for me down the line, even if it’s just a small step. I also don’t want to let my PI down after all the time and resources they’ve put into me, you know?

It sounds like you're driven by a combination of hope for future opportunities and a sense of responsibility to your PI. That's a lot of weight to carry, and it's clear you're doing your best to balance your own needs with the expectations of others. I wonder, what would it be like to imagine a future where this grant does pan out and those doors do open?

Honestly, imagining a future where this grant works out feels both exciting and kinda far-off. Like, I can picture having that achievement under my belt, maybe getting some recognition or a better shot at a job or fellowship, but right now it just feels like a distant dream with all the hurdles I’m facing.

It's inspiring to hear how you're holding onto that vision of a future where the grant pays off, even with the challenges you're facing right now. What would it mean for you to start bridging that gap between the distant dream and the present moment, step by step?

I guess it would mean breaking things down into smaller, manageable pieces instead of feeling overwhelmed by the whole process. Like, maybe focusing on just getting through this meeting about my data this week, and not worrying so much about the bigger picture right now, you know?

That sounds like a wise approach, taking it one step at a time and focusing on what you can control right now. What if we explore some specific strategies that might help you stay grounded and focused as you prepare for this meeting and move forward with the grant?
Yeah, I’d really appreciate that. I’m feeling so scattered right now, and having some concrete ways to stay on track would help me not spiral into worrying about everything at once.

One strategy could be to create a checklist of tasks leading up to the meeting, prioritizing them based on importance and urgency. Another idea is to schedule regular check-ins with yourself or a trusted colleague to review progress and address any concerns as they arise. Lastly, consider setting aside dedicated time each day for focused work on the grant, minimizing distractions during that time. Which of these strategies resonates most with you?

Honestly, the checklist idea really clicks with me because I’m the kind of person who feels better when I can see what needs to be done in front of me. I think starting with that could help me organize my headspace and not feel like I’m drowning in a million things at once.

That's a great choice! The checklist can serve as a visual roadmap, helping you stay on track and make steady progress without getting bogged down by the bigger picture. What specific tasks do you think should be on that checklist to help you feel prepared for the meeting and move closer to your goal?

I think I’d start with stuff like reviewing my prelim data one more time to make sure I’ve got all the key points ready to discuss, and maybe jotting down some questions or concerns I wanna bring up with my PI and co-mentor. Also, probably adding a task to double-check any analysis they wanted done differently, just to feel confident I’m not missing anything before we sit down.

It's great to see you've identified specific tasks that will help you feel prepared for the meeting and move closer to your goal. Remember, the checklist is a tool to help you stay organized and focused, so don't hesitate to adjust it as needed. Also, don't forget to celebrate your progress along the way, no matter how small. You've made significant strides in managing your stress and tackling this project, and that's something to be proud of.

Thanks, I really appreciate the reminder to celebrate the small wins—it’s easy to forget that when I’m so focused on the end goal. So, before we wrap up, do you have any quick tips on how to keep myself from overthinking while I’m working through this checklist?

Absolutely! One strategy you could try is setting a timer for each task on your checklist. When the timer goes off, take a short break to stretch, move around, or do something that takes your mind off the task at hand. This can help break up the monotony of the work and give your mind a chance to reset. Additionally, try to reframe your thoughts when you catch yourself overthinking. Instead of focusing on potential negative outcomes, remind yourself that you're making progress and that each task completed brings you closer to your goal. Lastly, consider practicing mindfulness techniques, such as deep breathing or meditation, to help calm your mind and reduce stress.

Thanks for those ideas—I think setting a timer and taking breaks could really help me stay grounded. Do you think starting with just 5-minute breaks would be enough, or should I aim for longer ones to really step away?

concern:
I graduated college less than a year ago (May 2022); and my undergraduate experience was already screwed up by COVID-19 - I was forced to skip out on a full year before returning to Senior year because the US did not allow international students to take hybrid classes and my university was not offering at least 3 in-person classes for me during the 2020 - 2021 lockdown. So I got to watch all my friends graduate without me; I did qualify for an accelerated Master's Program in Economics and I was accepted but I opted not to pursue it due to COVID-19 and feeling that I did not want to stay in Fordham for both undergraduate and graduate school.  


Anyway, I somehow managed to get a short-term contract at the World Bank since they hired people from around the world, and if I work for the World Bank in a full-time job for about 15 years I am eligible for permanent residency (green card). For all intents and purposes I really want to stay and live and build a life in the US (especially now with geopolitical events in SE Asia). The problem is that I don't have options for employment in the private sector because the H1-b process is absurdly random and difficult; and the World Bank and IMF have outright told me that I can't get a fulltime job without AT LEAST a Master's Degree (it's already brutally difficult for me to get even a short-term contract role, let alone a fulltime job); and even this employment is not guaranteed.  


I'm thinking of getting a Master's Degree in Statistics or Data Science (an MBA or Master's degree in economics isn't very helpful) but I have checked that I did not take enough undergrad courses in Math or Computer Science to qualify (at least in the US). I'm fairly certain that my math skills and coding skills are nowhere near good enough for grad school (I struggled for a 3.60 gpa even before COVID-19)  
I'm honestly totally lost because I'm being forced to prepare for grad school so soon, just after I managed to find something solid career-wise (I'm 23 turning 24). Otherwise I have to go back to the Philippines and I probably won't have an opportunity to immigrate elsewhere anymore.  


Any advice for my circumstances?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm so glad you're here. Feel free to share anything that's been on your mind, and know that you're in a safe, judgment-free space. What would you like to talk about today?
Hey, thanks for having me. I’ve just been feeling really overwhelmed with my career and grad school decisions, especially with everything hinging on staying in the US.

That sounds incredibly stressful. It can be really tough to feel like so much is riding on one decision. Can you tell me a bit more about what’s been overwhelming you about your career and grad school choices?
Yeah, it’s just a lot to handle all at once. I feel like I’m stuck between needing to jump into grad school to secure my future here, but I’m not even sure I’m ready or qualified for it.

It's understandable to feel that way, especially when the stakes are high. I imagine it can be really hard to feel confident in your decision-making when there's so much uncertainty around your future. Can you tell me a bit more about what makes you doubt your readiness or qualifications for grad school?

Yeah, I just don’t think I have the background or skills for the programs I’m looking at, like in stats or data science. It’s stressing me out because I feel like I’m running out of time to figure this out.

That's a lot to carry on your shoulders. It's understandable that you'd feel unsure about your readiness when the programs you're interested in have such specific requirements. Can you tell me a bit more about what you're hoping to gain from grad school, and what you think is holding you back from feeling confident in your abilities?

Honestly, I’m hoping grad school will give me the credentials I need to secure a stable job here in the US and build a long-term future. But I keep doubting myself because my math and coding skills feel so weak, and I’m worried I won’t even get accepted or be able to keep up if I do.

That sounds like a really challenging and stressful situation to be in, especially when you feel like your future is on the line. It's important to remember that grad school is a place to learn and grow, not a test of your current abilities. What do you think would need to happen for you to feel more confident in your decision-making around grad school?

I guess I’d need to know that I can actually handle the coursework and not just crash and burn. Like, maybe if I could take some prep classes or get a better sense of what I’m getting into, I’d feel less freaked out about the whole thing.

It sounds like you're feeling caught between the desire for a stable future and the fear of not being prepared for grad school. I can see how taking some prep classes or getting a better sense of what the coursework entails could help alleviate some of that anxiety. Have you thought about what steps you could take to start exploring those options?

Yeah, I’ve thought about it a bit, but I’m not really sure where to start or if I even have the time and money to take extra classes right now. I just feel stuck, like I need to make a move but don’t know which direction to go.

It sounds like you're caught between a desire for a stable future and the fear of not being prepared for grad school. Taking prep classes or getting a better sense of the coursework could alleviate some anxiety, but you're unsure where to start or if you have the time and money. I understand feeling stuck, but perhaps we can explore possible directions together.

Yeah, I’d really appreciate that because I’m just spinning my wheels here and getting nowhere. I’m worried I’ll miss my chance if I don’t figure this out soon, so any help in narrowing down options would be huge.

Let's work together to help you find a direction. Have you thought about talking to your academic advisor or a counselor at your current university to explore possible resources or options for preparing for grad school?

Yeah, I haven’t reached out to an advisor yet, mostly because I’ve been so overwhelmed just trying to keep up with work and life. I guess I’m also kinda nervous they’ll just tell me I’m not cut out for it or something, but I know I should at least try to get some guidance.

It's understandable to feel overwhelmed, and reaching out for guidance can be a courageous step. I can see that you're eager to explore your options and move forward, even if it feels daunting right now. What would it be like to take that first step and talk to your advisor, knowing that you're seeking support rather than judgment?

Honestly, I think it’d be a relief to just get some clarity, even if it’s a bit scary to put myself out there. I’m just worried I’ll hear something I don’t want to, but I guess I won’t know until I try, right?

It’s natural to feel apprehensive about seeking guidance, but taking that first step can be empowering and lead to valuable insights. Reaching out to your advisor might help you identify available resources and strategies to better prepare for grad school, even if it feels daunting at first. What do you think is the most pressing question you'd want to ask your advisor, and how could we break down this step into smaller, manageable actions?

I think the most pressing question for my advisor would be whether there’s any way I can make up for the gaps in my math or coding skills to even qualify for a grad program. Maybe we could start by just helping me draft an email or figure out what to say, so I don’t feel so lost when I reach out?

That sounds like a great starting point! Let's work together to craft an email or plan your conversation with your advisor. How would you like to approach it—would you prefer to focus on your math skills, coding abilities, or both when discussing your concerns?

I’d probably want to focus on both math and coding since those are the big gaps holding me back right now. I just don’t even know where to start with explaining my situation without sounding like I’m totally clueless, so any help with that would be awesome.

That’s completely understandable, and it’s great that you want to address both areas. Let’s start by drafting an email or conversation outline that highlights your awareness of these gaps and your willingness to improve. How about we begin with something like, “I’m reaching out to discuss my preparation for grad school, specifically my math and coding skills. I’m eager to understand the best ways to strengthen these areas and would appreciate any guidance or recommendations you might have.” Does that feel like a good starting point for you?

Yeah, that sounds like a solid way to kick things off without feeling like I’m just floundering. Can we maybe tweak it a bit to also mention my background briefly, just so they get why I’ve got these gaps, or should I keep it super short for now?

Including a brief mention of your background could help provide context for your advisor, but let's keep it concise to avoid overwhelming them. How about adding a sentence like, “My undergraduate studies focused on [your major], which didn't heavily emphasize math and coding, so I'm eager to bridge that gap.” This way, you're offering insight into your background without losing focus on your main goal. What do you think?

Yeah, I like that addition—it feels right to give a little context without going into a whole life story. Do you think we could work on the full draft now, or should we brainstorm a bit more on how to word the part about asking for specific resources or courses to help me catch up?

Let's work on the full draft together, incorporating the background sentence we discussed. Here's a suggested draft for the email:
Subject: Seeking Guidance on Grad School Preparation and Skill Development
Dear [Advisor's Name],
I hope this email finds you well. I'm reaching out to discuss my preparation for grad school, specifically my math and coding skills. My undergraduate studies focused on [your major], which didn't heavily emphasize math and coding, so I'm eager to bridge that gap and strengthen these areas.
I would greatly appreciate any guidance or recommendations you might have on resources, courses, or strategies to help me improve my math and coding abilities. I am committed to putting in the necessary effort to ensure I am well-prepared for graduate studies.
Thank you for your time and consideration. I look forward to discussing this further with you and exploring ways to address my skill gaps.
Best regards,
[Your Name]
This draft maintains a focus on your primary concerns while providing some context for your advisor. Feel free to modify it as needed to best represent your situation.

Hey, this draft looks really good—thanks for putting it together. I think it hits the right tone, and I might just tweak a couple of words to make it sound a bit more like me, but overall, I’m feeling pretty confident about sending this out.

concern:
I’m a second year undergrad thinking of pursuing PhD in population biology/ecology. As I’m entering the summer, I plan to continue a research project I’ve worked on throughout the summer, although since meetings with my PI will become remote, I expect that to slow down.

Therefore, I’m looking for something meaningful to fill the rest of my days! (I haven’t applied to anything ahead of time) It could be something that pads my grad school application, or just something that gives me the chance to learn and grow.

So, what are things you would have done in your freshman/sophomore summer? 3 months is a whole lot of time, and while many people say it’s fine to just enjoy it (junior year is when you should really get something serious under your belt), I don’t want to spend this summer with heaps of free time like freshman summer. I’m open to doing some self learning/personal projects but from past experience this has been really hard to keep going.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there, I'm so glad you're here. I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about today?

Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just feeling a bit stuck about how to make the most of my summer as a second-year undergrad interested in a PhD in population biology or ecology, and I’d really like to figure out some meaningful ways to spend my time.

That sounds like a really important time for you to explore your interests and make the most of your opportunities. It's great that you're thinking ahead and wanting to make the most of your summer. What kinds of things have you been considering for your summer plans?

Hey, I’ve been thinking about continuing a research project I’m already on, though it’ll slow down with remote meetings. I’m also just kinda brainstorming other stuff to do that could help with grad school apps or just help me grow, but I’m not totally sure where to start.

That's great that you have a research project to continue, and it's understandable that you want to make the most of your time this summer. It sounds like you're thinking about both your current project and other opportunities that could help you grow and prepare for grad school. Can you tell me a bit more about the research project you're working on and what kinds of things you're hoping to achieve with it?

Hey, yeah, I’m happy to talk about it. The project is focused on some ecological modeling stuff, and I’m hoping it’ll give me a deeper understanding of population dynamics while also looking good on my CV for grad school apps.

It sounds like your current research project aligns well with your interests in population biology and ecology, and it's great that you're thinking about how it can benefit your future grad school applications. What are some other experiences or opportunities you've been considering for this summer that could help you grow as a researcher and prepare for your future goals?

Hey, I’m glad you think the project fits with my goals. I’ve been tossing around ideas like maybe finding an online course or workshop related to ecology or data analysis to build some skills, or even trying to connect with other researchers or students for networking, but I’m kinda unsure how to make that happen or if it’s even worth the effort this early on.

That's a thoughtful approach, and it sounds like you're considering a variety of ways to grow and prepare for your future goals. It's understandable to feel unsure about the best path forward, but it's great that you're open to exploring different opportunities and seeking connections that could be valuable in your field.

Hey, thanks for saying that, I appreciate the encouragement. I guess I just worry about whether stuff like online courses or reaching out to people will actually make a difference, you know, or if I’m just spinning my wheels when I could be focusing on something else.

That's a valid concern, and it's natural to question whether certain efforts will pay off. One way to approach this could be to think about the potential benefits and drawbacks of each opportunity, and weigh them against your goals and priorities. For example, taking an online course might help you build specific skills that could be valuable in your research project or future grad school applications, while connecting with other researchers could lead to new ideas, collaborations, or mentorship opportunities. By considering these potential outcomes, you can make a more informed decision about how to allocate your time and energy this summer.

Hey, that makes a lot of sense, thanks for breaking it down like that. I think I’ll start by looking into a couple of online courses that focus on stats or modeling since those skills could directly help with my project, but I’m still kinda nervous about the networking part—any tips on how to even start reaching out to people without feeling super awkward?

It's completely normal to feel nervous about reaching out to people, but it's great that you're thinking about how to approach it in a way that feels comfortable and authentic. One tip might be to start small, by connecting with people you already have a connection with, such as professors, advisors, or peers who share your research interests. You could also try reaching out to people who have published work in your field, or who are involved in organizations or conferences related to your research. Remember, many people in academia and research are happy to offer advice and guidance to students who are genuinely interested in their work.

Hey, thanks for the advice, that actually sounds pretty doable. I think I’ll start by emailing a prof I’ve had a class with and maybe check out some online forums or groups related to ecology to see if I can join in on discussions without it feeling too forced.

It sounds like you're developing a solid plan for the summer, focusing on both skill-building and networking. What steps do you think would be most helpful to tackle first, and how might you anticipate potential challenges or setbacks along the way?

Hey, I’m glad you think it’s a solid plan. I think starting with that email to my prof is the first step since it feels less intimidating, and then I’ll look into those online forums; as for challenges, I’m kinda worried I might not get responses or I’ll come off as annoying, so maybe I need to figure out how to keep my messages short and to the point.

That's a great way to start, and your awareness of potential challenges is a good sign of your proactive approach. You could also consider practicing your email and messages with a trusted friend or advisor to get feedback and refine your approach. Additionally, you might think about how you'll handle any setbacks or disappointments, such as not getting responses, so that you can stay motivated and focused on your goals.

Hey, thanks for suggesting that idea about practicing my emails with someone I trust—that actually feels like a good way to ease my nerves a bit. I guess if I don’t get responses, I’ll just try to remind myself not to take it personally and maybe reach out to a couple more people or look for other ways to connect, like joining webinars or something; do you think that’s a decent backup plan?

It sounds like you're thinking through this thoroughly, and that's great. Your backup plan seems solid, as it gives you multiple avenues to explore and helps you stay proactive in the face of potential setbacks.

Hey, I’m really glad you think the backup plan sounds solid. I’m feeling a bit more confident now, but I’m still kinda wondering how to balance all this networking stuff with my ongoing research project over the summer, since I don’t want to drop the ball on that either.

Great to hear that your confidence is growing! Balancing networking and research can be challenging, but there are some strategies you can use to manage your time effectively. One idea is to set aside specific times each day or week for networking, such as an hour or two in the morning or evening, while dedicating the rest of your time to research. This way, you can focus on each task without feeling overwhelmed.
Another approach is to integrate your networking efforts with your research. For example, if you're working on a project related to population dynamics, you could look for online forums or webinars focused on that topic, which would allow you to network with experts in the field while also staying current with the latest research and developments.
Remember, the key is to find a balance that works for you and to be flexible. If you find that your current plan isn't working as well as you'd hoped, don't hesitate to adjust it. The important thing is to keep moving forward and stay committed to your goals.

Hey, thanks for the tips on balancing things—I like the idea of setting specific times for networking so it doesn’t spill over into my research. Do you think it’s okay to start with just a small chunk of time each week and then adjust if I feel like I can handle more?

concern:
I’m in a History MA program (graduating in May!) and it’s been a big struggle but the worst part is the complete lack of standard expectations.

Over the summer (2021) all of my cohort had to do an internship. At the end of the internship we had to write a reflection essay about our experiences. However, this essay is reviewed by our advisor and depending on what they want the essays are very different. Most were 4-5 pages with a lot of self-reflection, one or two people got away with 1-2 pages. 

But my advisor (who only has me as an advisee as they are on sabbatical) asked for a ten page paper which they have  returned FOUR  times for more editing. This most recent return they are asking me to add at least four paragraphs were I explain some books related to the internship topic, what their main points were, and how I felt those were reflected in my internship. No one else in my cohort was asked to do this but since I need advisor approval I am stuck adding all their demands. I’m the last one still working on this essay.

Also it needs to be submitted before the 21st so I can graduate so on top of finishing my capstone, regular work for class, and helping a sick family member, I have to work on this stupid essay. My advisor is completely aware of all of this too. And since they are on sabbatical it can be up to a month before I get a response. I’m just so frustrated!!!!

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! I'm so glad you're here. I'd love to hear what's been on your mind lately—whatever feels important to you right now, I'm all ears. Take your time, and know that you're in a safe space to share as much or as little as you'd like.

Hey, thanks for being here to listen. I’m just really overwhelmed with some stuff in my grad program and personal life, and it’s all piling up in a way that’s hard to handle.

Man, I don’t even know where to start. Like, I’ve been grinding through this History MA, and I’m so close to graduating in May, but there’s this one stupid thing with my advisor that’s driving me up the wall. And on top of that, I’ve got family stuff and other deadlines just crushing me. I’m so frustrated and tired, you know?

That sounds like a really heavy load to carry all at once—especially when you’re so close to finishing your program. I can see how that one issue with your advisor might feel like the final straw, adding insult to injury when everything else is already weighing you down. What’s been the most frustrating part about dealing with them?

Honestly, the most frustrating part is just the inconsistency and feeling like I’m being singled out with extra demands that nobody else has to deal with. It’s like I’m stuck jumping through hoops that keep getting higher while everyone else is already done.

I just don’t get why it has to be this way, you know? Like, I’m already drowning with everything else on my plate, and now I’ve got to keep rewriting and adding stuff to this one assignment when I thought it was over months ago. It feels so unfair, and I’m worried I won’t even get it done in time with how slow the feedback is. How am I supposed to handle all this without completely losing it?

It's completely understandable that you'd feel this way, especially when you're already carrying so much. The inconsistency and added pressure from your advisor must make it feel like you're constantly battling an uphill climb. It's important to acknowledge that these feelings of frustration and unfairness are valid, and it's okay to take a step back and focus on your well-being amidst all of this. Let's see if we can work together to find ways to manage your workload and make the situation with your advisor more manageable.

Thanks, I really appreciate you saying that—it helps to know I’m not just overreacting or something. I’d love to figure out some ways to get through this without feeling like I’m gonna break.

Like, I just don’t even know how to approach my advisor about this without sounding like I’m complaining, you know? And with the deadline so close, I’m freaking out that even if I do everything they want, it might not get approved in time. Plus, I’ve got all this other stuff pulling at me, and I feel like I’m dropping the ball everywhere. What can I even do to start getting a grip on this mess?

It sounds like you're caught in a whirlwind of demands and uncertainties, and it's totally reasonable to feel like you're at your breaking point. Let's take a breath and focus on one thing at a time. When it comes to approaching your advisor, maybe we can start by brainstorming some strategies to help you communicate your concerns without feeling like you're coming across as negative. And as for managing your workload, it might be helpful to prioritize your tasks and break them down into smaller, more manageable chunks. What do you think?

Yeah, that sounds like a good place to start—I’m definitely down to brainstorm how to talk to my advisor without it feeling like I’m just whining. And breaking things into smaller bits might help me not feel so buried, so I’m willing to give that a shot.

I guess with my advisor, I just worry they’ll think I’m not committed or something if I push back at all, you know? Like, I don’t even know how to bring up that their extra demands are messing with me, especially since they’re on sabbatical and already hard to reach. And with everything else, I’m just so scattered—how do I even figure out what to tackle first when it all feels urgent? I’m kinda lost on where to begin.

It's completely understandable that you're worried about how your advisor might perceive your concerns, especially when they're already difficult to reach. Let's start by reframing your approach as a proactive, collaborative effort to ensure the best possible outcome for your project, rather than a complaint. Perhaps you could reach out to your advisor with a message like, ""I'm excited about the progress I've made on this assignment, and I want to make sure I'm meeting your expectations. Could we schedule a time to discuss any remaining concerns or revisions?"" This way, you're showing your commitment while also opening the door for a productive conversation.
Regarding your scattered feelings, it might help to take a moment to assess which tasks are truly urgent versus which ones can wait. Try asking yourself, ""Which task will have the most significant impact if completed first?"" or ""Which task can I realistically complete within the next few hours or days?"" By prioritizing based on these questions, you'll be able to focus your energy on the most critical tasks and make steady progress without feeling overwhelmed.

Thanks for the suggestion on how to frame things with my advisor—that wording feels way less confrontational, and I think I can work with that. I’m just nervous about even getting a response in time with how slow they’ve been, but I’ll give it a try and see if I can get some clarity.

And yeah, figuring out what’s most urgent makes sense, though honestly, everything feels like it’s screaming at me right now. I guess I can try to list out my tasks and pick one or two to focus on each day—like maybe start with the essay revisions since that’s tied to my graduation—but I’m still kinda overwhelmed just thinking about it all. How do I keep myself from spiraling when I look at that list and feel like there’s no way I can get it all done?

It’s okay to feel overwhelmed by the sheer number of tasks. You don’t have to tackle everything at once. Let’s focus on one or two tasks for the day, and remember that every step you take, no matter how small, is progress. When you start to spiral, take a deep breath and remind yourself that you’re doing the best you can. It’s also important to practice self-compassion and acknowledge that it’s normal to feel this way when you’re juggling so much. You’re not alone in this, and it’s okay to ask for help when you need it.

Thanks for reminding me to take it one step at a time—I really needed to hear that. I’ll try to focus on just a couple things each day and keep telling myself it’s okay if I don’t get everything done right away.

I guess I’m just scared that even if I break it down, I’ll still fall behind, especially with my advisor’s slow responses. It’s like I’m trying to stay on top of stuff, but there’s always something out of my control messing things up. How do I deal with that frustration when it feels like no matter what I do, I’m still stuck waiting or stressing?

It’s understandable to feel frustrated when things are out of your control, but remember that you can still focus on the things you can control, like your own work and communication. It might help to reframe your mindset from seeing these delays as roadblocks to seeing them as opportunities to work on other tasks or take a break to recharge. Remember, progress is progress, no matter how slow it may seem. Keep in mind that you’re not alone in this, and it’s okay to ask for help when you need it.

Thanks for pointing that out—I hadn’t thought about using the waiting time as a chance to focus on other stuff or just take a breather. I’ll try to shift my thinking and see if that helps with the frustration.

I’m just still kinda stuck on how to not let the waiting stress me out, you know? Like, I get that I can work on other things, but in the back of my mind, I’m always worrying about whether I’ll hear back in time or if I’m gonna miss some deadline. How do I quiet that nagging voice that keeps freaking me out about stuff I can’t control?

It sounds like you're already making progress by acknowledging the waiting time as an opportunity to focus on other tasks or take a break. Remember that it's normal to feel some level of stress or worry when waiting for responses, but try to remind yourself that you've done your part by reaching out and communicating your needs. 
Instead of letting the nagging voice take over, try to acknowledge the worry and gently refocus your attention on what you can control. For example, you could say to yourself, ""I've done what I can for now, and I'll revisit this concern when I receive a response."" This can help quiet the worrying thoughts and allow you to move forward with the tasks at hand.

Thanks for the tip on acknowledging the worry and redirecting my focus—I think that could really help with calming that constant nagging in my head. I’ll try telling myself I’ve done what I can and just let it be for now.

It’s just hard to not keep checking my email every five minutes, you know? Like, I’m so anxious about missing something or not having enough time to fix stuff if my advisor finally gets back to me. How do I stop myself from obsessing over that and actually focus on other things?

One approach could be to set a specific time to check your email, maybe once or twice a day, and try to avoid checking it outside of those times. This can help break the cycle of constant checking and reduce the anxiety that comes with it. You could also try setting up notifications or reminders for when you need to check your email, so you can focus on other tasks without worrying about missing something important.

Thanks for the idea of setting specific times to check my email—that sounds like it could really help me stop obsessing over it. I’ll try to pick a couple of times a day and stick to that instead of constantly refreshing.

I’m just worried that even with a schedule, I’ll still be thinking about it, you know? Like, what if I’m in the middle of working on something else and I just can’t shake the thought that I might be missing a crucial reply? How do I train myself to let go of that urge to keep checking just in case?

That's a valid concern, and it's important to acknowledge those thoughts without judgment. One strategy could be to create a ""worry journal"" or a ""concern list"" where you write down the thoughts and worries that pop up throughout the day. This can help you acknowledge and process those thoughts without letting them interrupt your focus. You could also try pairing this with a grounding exercise, like deep breathing or a quick mindfulness meditation, to help calm your mind and bring your attention back to the present moment.

Thanks for suggesting the worry journal and grounding exercises—that sounds like a practical way to get those nagging thoughts out of my head without letting them take over. I’ll definitely give that a shot and see if writing stuff down helps me feel less stuck on it.

I guess I’m also just feeling kinda overwhelmed with how much is on my plate right now, you know? Like, even if I manage to stop obsessing over the email, I’ve still got so many other things piling up that it’s hard to know where to start. How do I even begin to prioritize when everything feels urgent?

One strategy to help you prioritize when everything feels urgent is to use the Eisenhower Matrix, which categorizes tasks into four quadrants based on their urgency and importance. This can help you identify which tasks are truly urgent and important, and which ones can be delegated, postponed, or eliminated. You can also try using a task list or planner to break down your tasks into smaller, manageable steps and focus on completing one step at a time.

Thanks for bringing up the Eisenhower Matrix and the idea of breaking tasks into smaller steps—that sounds like a solid way to get a handle on things. I’ll try mapping out what’s most urgent and important to see if that helps me feel less buried.

I just keep feeling like no matter how I organize stuff, there’s not enough time in the day, you know? Like, I’m juggling so much that even the idea of sitting down to prioritize feels like another task on the list. How do I deal with that sinking feeling that I’m always gonna be behind?

I understand your frustration, and it's important to remember that managing your workload and prioritizing tasks is a skill that takes time and practice to develop. Be patient with yourself, and don't hesitate to reach out for support when you need it. Here's a summary of the strategies we discussed:
- Set specific times to check your email to reduce the urge to constantly refresh and decrease anxiety.
- Use a ""worry journal"" or ""concern list"" to write down thoughts and worries that pop up throughout the day, and pair this with grounding exercises like deep breathing or mindfulness meditation to help calm your mind.
- Utilize the Eisenhower Matrix to categorize tasks based on their urgency and importance, and break down tasks into smaller, manageable steps.
- Consider using a task list or planner to keep track of your tasks and deadlines, and focus on completing one step at a time.
Our next session will focus on further exploring these strategies and identifying any additional tools that can help you manage your workload and reduce stress. Remember to be kind to yourself and celebrate small victories along the way.

Thanks for summarizing everything we’ve talked about—I really appreciate having those strategies to lean on. I’ll do my best to be patient with myself and start small.

Hey, before we wrap up, do you think it’s okay if I check in with you sooner if I’m still feeling really swamped? I just want to make sure I’m not letting things spiral too much.

therapist: One approach could be to set a specific time to check your email, maybe once or twice a day, and try to avoid checking it outside of those times. This can help break the cycle of constant checking and reduce the anxiety that comes with it. You could also try setting up notifications or reminders for when you need to check your email, so you can focus on other tasks without worrying about missing something important.
client: Thanks for the idea of setting specific times to check my email—that sounds like it could really help me stop obsessing over it. I’ll try to pick a couple of times a day and stick to that instead of constantly refreshing.

I’m just worried that even with a schedule, I’ll still be thinking about it, you know? Like, what if I’m in the middle of working on something else and I just can’t shake the thought that I might be missing a crucial reply? How do I train myself to let go of that urge to keep checking just in case?
therapist: That's a valid concern, and it's important to acknowledge those thoughts without judgment. One strategy could be to create a ""worry journal"" or a ""concern list"" where you write down the thoughts and worries that pop up throughout the day. This can help you acknowledge and process those thoughts without letting them interrupt your focus. You could also try pairing this with a grounding exercise, like deep breathing or a quick mindfulness meditation, to help calm your mind and bring your attention back to the present moment.
client: Thanks for suggesting the worry journal and grounding exercises—that sounds like a practical way to get those nagging thoughts out of my head without letting them take over. I’ll definitely give that a shot and see if writing stuff down helps me feel less stuck on it.

I guess I’m also just feeling kinda overwhelmed with how much is on my plate right now, you know? Like, even if I manage to stop obsessing over the email, I’ve still got so many other things piling up that it’s hard to know where to start. How do I even begin to prioritize when everything feels urgent?
therapist: One strategy to help you prioritize when everything feels urgent is to use the Eisenhower Matrix, which categorizes tasks into four quadrants based on their urgency and importance. This can help you identify which tasks are truly urgent and important, and which ones can be delegated, postponed, or eliminated. You can also try using a task list or planner to break down your tasks into smaller, manageable steps and focus on completing one step at a time.
client: Thanks for bringing up the Eisenhower Matrix and the idea of breaking tasks into smaller steps—that sounds like a solid way to get a handle on things. I’ll try mapping out what’s most urgent and important to see if that helps me feel less buried.

I just keep feeling like no matter how I organize stuff, there’s not enough time in the day, you know? Like, I’m juggling so much that even the idea of sitting down to prioritize feels like another task on the list. How do I deal with that sinking feeling that I’m always gonna be behind?
therapist: I understand your frustration, and it's important to remember that managing your workload and prioritizing tasks is a skill that takes time and practice to develop. Be patient with yourself, and don't hesitate to reach out for support when you need it. Here's a summary of the strategies we discussed:
- Set specific times to check your email to reduce the urge to constantly refresh and decrease anxiety.
- Use a ""worry journal"" or ""concern list"" to write down thoughts and worries that pop up throughout the day, and pair this with grounding exercises like deep breathing or mindfulness meditation to help calm your mind.
- Utilize the Eisenhower Matrix to categorize tasks based on their urgency and importance, and break down tasks into smaller, manageable steps.
- Consider using a task list or planner to keep track of your tasks and deadlines, and focus on completing one step at a time.
Our next session will focus on further exploring these strategies and identifying any additional tools that can help you manage your workload and reduce stress. Remember to be kind to yourself and celebrate small victories along the way.
client: Thanks for summarizing everything we’ve talked about—I really appreciate having those strategies to lean on. I’ll do my best to be patient with myself and start small.

Hey, before we wrap up, do you think it’s okay if I check in with you sooner if I’m still feeling really swamped? I just want to make sure I’m not letting things spiral too much.

concern:
So first time I took the comp exam (civil engineering), I was told I passed! I told everyone and celebrated and moved on with my life.

2 weeks after grades were posted I was told it was a clerical error and that I did not pass. I was crushed, as you can imagine. What made things even worse was when more people would congratulate me after I found out it was an error. I decided not to tell anyone of this error (except my wife and parents) in hopes that I would pass the second attempt.

Unfortunately, I failed that test too. So now, the committee has given me another opportunity to get my hard earned diploma. I don't know if this is common, or that they're just giving me a break for crushing my life after informing me of the clerical error mishap. The task is an oral exam with a single written question on the most difficult course I've taken, and I'm which I did the absolute worst in.

The test is in less than a month, and I have approximately 3 full weekends to study and I have been given big hints for the question.

I am now in the works of pairing with a professional tutor and am preparing all my questions for the time with the tutor.

I have been really unable to sleep through the night these passed few days from the severe anxiety I am feeling. So, what should I do during the week that I am not working with the tutor?

Should I just continue to review during the week? Btw I have a full time demanding engineering job at which I come home around 7:30 during the week.

Sorry if I'm all over the place, I just want to know what I should do so I can finally put this behind me.

Edit- I passed the exam! Thanks to everyone's support and for sharing their experience with me.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! It's so great to have you here. Feel free to share whatever's on your mind - I'm all ears and ready to listen.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’ve just been really stressed lately with some academic stuff that’s been weighing on me hard.

I'm really sorry to hear that you've been feeling so stressed lately. Academic pressures can be incredibly overwhelming, and I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Would you like to tell me more about what's been going on?
Yeah, I’d appreciate that. It’s just been a rollercoaster with some unexpected setbacks, and I’m struggling to keep my head above water with everything piling up.

That sounds like an incredibly tough situation to be in, and it's completely understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed. I want you to know that you're not alone in this, and I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Would you like to share a bit more about what these setbacks have been like for you?
Yeah, for sure. It’s just been a lot of ups and downs, and I’m constantly worried about not being able to get past this hurdle, ya know?

I can only imagine how tough it must be to feel like you're constantly navigating a rollercoaster of setbacks and pressures. It's completely understandable that you're worried about not being able to get past this hurdle, and I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Would you like to share a bit more about what these setbacks have been like for you, and how they've been affecting your daily life?
Yeah, definitely. It’s just been draining, you know, like I’m carrying this weight all the time, and it’s messing with my sleep and focus big time.

It sounds like you've been carrying a heavy load for a while now, and I'm glad you're opening up about it. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been going through your mind when you're feeling overwhelmed and struggling to focus?
Yeah, for sure. It’s like my mind just won’t shut off, you know, constantly running through all the things I need to get done and worrying I’m gonna mess up again.

It sounds like your mind is constantly racing, making it difficult to find a moment of peace. It must be exhausting to feel like you're constantly on edge, worried about the next setback or mistake. Can you tell me more about what it would mean to you if you could find a way to quiet that inner voice and feel more in control of your thoughts and emotions?
Yeah, that would mean everything to me, honestly. Like, just being able to take a deep breath and not feel this constant knot in my chest would be such a relief, you know?

That's a powerful image you've painted. It sounds like you're craving a sense of peace and control in your life, and I can understand why that would feel like such a relief. Can you tell me more about what it would be like for you to feel that sense of calm and confidence, and how you might go about achieving it?

Yeah, I think if I could feel that calm and confidence, it’d be like a huge weight off my shoulders, like I could finally just focus on the present without all this dread hanging over me. I’m not totally sure how to get there, but maybe figuring out some ways to manage my stress or talk myself down when I’m spiraling could help, you know?

That's a really insightful reflection. It sounds like you're already starting to identify some potential steps towards feeling more calm and in control. Can you tell me more about what it would be like for you to actually start taking those steps, and how you might begin to build those stress management skills?

Yeah, I think taking those steps would feel like I’m finally moving forward, like I’m actually doing something to get out of this constant loop of worry. I guess I could start by trying small things, like setting aside a few minutes each day to just breathe or write down what’s stressing me out, you know, just to get it out of my head.

That's a great idea to start small, creating space for yourself to process and release stress. How do you imagine incorporating these new habits into your daily routine, and what might help you stay consistent with them?

Honestly, I think fitting these habits in might be tough with my crazy schedule, but maybe I can carve out a few minutes right after work or before bed to just decompress. I guess setting a reminder on my phone or even telling my wife to nudge me about it could help me stick with it, you know?

That’s a solid plan, and it’s great that you’re considering how to weave these habits into your busy routine. What might happen if you do manage to carve out those few minutes each day to breathe or journal, and how might that small commitment start to shift your overall sense of control and calm?

I think if I can actually stick to those few minutes each day, it might start to feel like I’m taking back a bit of control, like I’m not just drowning in stress all the time. It could be a small win, you know, something to build on and maybe help me feel a little more grounded overall.

That sounds like a powerful step forward, especially if those small wins start to accumulate and build your confidence in managing stress. How do you think you might handle moments when life feels too hectic to carve out those few minutes, and what could help you stay connected to the progress you're making even on busy days?

I think on those super hectic days, I might just have to be okay with doing even less, like just taking a deep breath for a minute or two instead of a full journaling session. Maybe keeping a little note or app on my phone to jot down a quick thought or reminder of why I’m doing this could help me stay tied to the progress, even when I’m swamped.

It sounds like we've covered some great ground today. To recap, we've identified key goals such as carving out time for deep breathing and journaling, incorporating these habits into your daily routine, and staying consistent with the help of reminders or support from your wife. We've also explored the potential benefits of these small wins, including feeling more grounded and in control. Additionally, we've discussed strategies for managing hectic days, such as adapting your habits and staying connected to your progress through notes or apps. Remember, it's all about taking it one step at a time, and you've already shown great initiative by proposing these strategies and considering ways to integrate them into your life. As you move forward, try to be patient and kind to yourself, acknowledging that setbacks are a natural part of the process. And don't hesitate to reach out if you need further guidance or support.
Thanks for summarizing everything so clearly—it really helps to see it all laid out like that. I’ll do my best to take it slow and not beat myself up if things don’t go perfectly right away.

{{"reasoning": "The session has effectively summarized goals, coping strategies, and next steps. The client acknowledged the summary positively, indicating readiness to move forward independently with a clear plan.","determination": "stop"}}

That sounds overwhelming, and I can see how that chaotic morning routine might be setting the tone for the rest of the day. Let's see if we can identify some areas where we might be able to make adjustments to create a smoother start. Perhaps we could explore ways to prioritize a few key elements of your morning routine, or consider small changes that could help reduce the stress you're feeling during those first few hours of the day?
Hey, yeah, I’m totally open to finding ways to make my mornings less of a mess. I’d love to hear any ideas you’ve got for small changes that could help me feel less frazzled right from the start.

Based on what you've shared, possible options could include setting your alarm a bit earlier to allow for a more relaxed morning, preparing your breakfast the night before, or even taking a few deep breaths before rushing out the door. What do you think might work best for you?

Great work, [Client's Name]! You've already taken a significant step by acknowledging the importance of your morning routine in managing stress. I'm glad we could explore some options to make your mornings less chaotic. It's important to remember that small changes can lead to big improvements in the long run. 
Let's recap your action plan:
1. Set your alarm 15 minutes earlier to create a more relaxed morning.
2. Practice deep breathing exercises before rushing out the door to help you feel calmer.

Keep in mind that it's normal to feel overwhelmed sometimes, but with time and practice, you'll develop better coping mechanisms to handle your responsibilities and improve your overall well-being. You've got this!

client: Hey, thanks for the encouragement and for laying out those steps so clearly. I’m feeling hopeful about trying these out and seeing how they help with my mornings. So, before we wrap up, do you think we could touch on how I can keep myself motivated to stick with these changes?

concern:
So, many of you are probably in the same boat as me. I am working on graduating by the end of the semester, but I am kind of shitting my pants with how much I have left to do. There's still enough time, I still control my destiny, but the time is fast approaching where we won't have enough time/ be pulling all nighters to get done. And working another job while wrapping up my PhD on the side, I CANNOT do that...

I've set a goal to write 4 pages a day in February. Does anyone want to join me in this endeavor? If you write 4 pages (including today) from now until the end of the month, you have 88 pages. 3/4 to half of your dissertation. If you are doing a thesis that could be more than enough. I realize page count is kind of a stupid metric, but this is all fluid so do what's best for you. It could mean write more/less per day or switch to an editing goal. 

Anybody in? If so, let me know what your goal is and what you're writing about. If people want, I can post a new thread every Sunday. 

I am writing about tecno-economic implications of producing and selling non-electricity commodities from nuclear (hydrogen, clean water, etc). Goal is 4 pages per day average.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind, and we'll work through it together.
Thanks for being here, I really appreciate having someone to talk to about this. I’m just feeling super overwhelmed with everything I need to get done for my PhD and balancing work on top of it.

It sounds like you're juggling a lot right now, and it's totally understandable to feel overwhelmed. I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Can you tell me more about what's been feeling the most overwhelming lately?

Yeah, it’s just this constant pressure of deadlines creeping closer, and I’m worried I won’t get it all done in time. I’ve got a plan to push through, but it’s hard to keep up the pace without feeling like I’m drowning.

It’s clear how much effort and dedication you’re putting into your PhD and work, but the stress of deadlines can really take a toll. It’s normal to feel like you’re struggling to keep up, especially when there’s so much on the line. How have you been managing to cope with this pressure so far?

Honestly, I’ve been just trying to stick to a schedule, like setting daily goals for writing and stuff. It helps a bit, but some days I’m just so wiped out from work that I can barely focus, you know?

It's amazing how much effort you're putting into staying on top of things, and it sounds like your schedule is a helpful tool, even if it's not perfect. It's totally normal to feel drained after a long day at work, and it's great that you're being honest with yourself about your limits. How do you feel about the balance between your PhD and work right now - are there any parts of it that feel more manageable than others?

Honestly, the balance feels pretty off most of the time, like I’m constantly playing catch-up. I guess the writing goals are sorta manageable when I can focus, but work just drains so much energy that it’s hard to keep up momentum.

It sounds like your schedule has been a helpful anchor, even if it's been a bit rocky lately. I'm curious, what do you think might happen if you were able to carve out even a small bit of extra time for yourself each day - maybe to recharge or just breathe?

Honestly, I think even a tiny bit of extra time could make a huge difference, like just a moment to clear my head might help me focus better. I’m not sure how to make that happen with everything piling up, but it’s something I’d love to figure out.

It's interesting how even a small change in your daily routine could have a positive impact on your focus and overall well-being. What do you think would be the most challenging part of finding that extra time for yourself?

Honestly, the toughest part would probably be just letting go of the guilt of not working on something every second. Like, I feel this constant pressure to be productive, so stepping away even for a bit feels almost wrong, you know?

It's really insightful of you to recognize that guilt and pressure to be productive might be holding you back. That's a common challenge, and it's worth exploring how you can reframe self-care as a valuable investment in your overall well-being and productivity.

Yeah, I get that reframing it as an investment makes sense, but it’s hard to shake that nagging feeling that I’m slacking if I’m not grinding. I guess I just need some kinda way to convince myself that taking a break isn’t gonna derail everything I’m working toward.

It sounds like you're caught between wanting to prioritize self-care and the fear that it might hinder your progress. What if we explored how taking small breaks could actually enhance your focus and overall productivity, rather than detract from it?

Yeah, I’d be down to explore that, because I really do want to find a balance without feeling like I’m sabotaging myself. Like, if I could see proof that small breaks actually help me get more done, I think I could start to ease up on myself a bit.
That's a really interesting idea. Have you noticed any moments where taking a break actually helped you come back to a task with renewed energy and focus?

Yeah, I can think of a couple times when stepping away for a bit, like going for a quick walk, actually cleared my head and made it easier to dive back in. It’s just hard to remember that in the moment when I’m stressing about deadlines, you know?

It’s really helpful that you can reflect on those moments where taking a break actually helped you feel more focused and energized. Let’s brainstorm some specific strategies that could help you remember to step away and recharge when you’re feeling stressed about deadlines. Maybe we could try creating a simple routine or reminder system that signals to you that it’s time to take a break and give yourself permission to recharge?

Yeah, I think having some kind of reminder system could be really useful, especially since I tend to get so caught up in the grind that I forget to step back. Like, maybe setting a timer or something on my phone to nudge me to take a breather would help me actually stick to it.

That sounds like a solid starting point, and I love the idea of leveraging technology to support your self-care. What if we also brainstormed some other low-effort reminders, like setting a recurring calendar event or even using a physical timer on your desk? And maybe we could explore what kind of break activities feel most rejuvenating for you, so you can have a go-to list when the timer goes off?

Yeah, I’m totally open to trying out different reminders like a calendar event or a desk timer—those could be good backups if my phone doesn’t cut through the noise of my focus. And figuring out what kinds of breaks actually recharge me sounds super helpful, ‘cause sometimes I just stare at my phone and don’t really feel better after, you know?

That’s a great point about needing to find break activities that actually recharge you, not just distract you. Let’s build a personalized list of break ideas that feel meaningful and energizing to you, so you can choose one that works in the moment when the timer goes off.

Yeah, I’m all for coming up with a list of break ideas that actually leave me feeling refreshed instead of just killing time. I’m thinking maybe stuff like stepping outside for a few minutes or even just stretching at my desk could do the trick, but I’d love to hear any other suggestions you’ve got.

As we wrap up this session, I want to commend you for your self-awareness and willingness to explore strategies to support your well-being. Remember, taking breaks is essential for your productivity and overall health. To recap, we've discussed setting up reminders, such as a phone timer or calendar event, and creating a personalized list of rejuvenating break activities.
For the next step, I encourage you to start implementing these strategies and notice how they impact your productivity and stress levels. Don't forget to be kind to yourself and give yourself permission to take breaks when needed. Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and I'm here to support you along the way. Let's schedule a follow-up session to check in on your progress and continue working together to find the best balance for your PhD and work responsibilities.

Thanks for the encouragement and for summarizing our plan—I really appreciate the support. I’ll start trying out these reminders and break ideas this week and see how they feel. Can we schedule that follow-up for next month, maybe around the same time?

concern:
Hi all,

I am an MBA student in the back half of my program with 4 classes left. I am in the second most challenging class in the degree supposedly at the moment, and while it is a lot of work it didn't seem tough when given the time at the beginning of the semester. The issue is, I haven't been able to put the time in to succeed and it is really hitting me mentally, I can't decide what to do at the moment. 

I recently lost both my great aunt and uncle (basically my grandparents, the closest people in my life outside of my immediate family) within two weeks of each other and have had to travel across the USA to support my family and be there as my aunt passed away at the end. For reference, my aunt and uncle lived in the northeast while my family is located in southern FL. My immediate family is extremely close and my mother has been away from the family providing care every step of the way in conjunction with Hospice, not leaving their side since her arrival there in early September. On top of this, my maternal grandparents and maternal uncle (who have been mentally abusive of my mother for my entire life, the reason we moved down south) have been treating the family terribly and causing additional stress for my family and quite frankly I don't know how my mother has been able to deal with this whole thing. My uncle is a troublemaker who has been enabled throughout his life by my grandparents and has been to jail a few times for various issues that should have landed him more time in lockup. The conflict this time is over the fact certain people were not included in the will, and my mom is being blamed for us having control of the estate. We had a bat by the door the whole time we were at my great aunt and uncle's house and all decided nobody is leaving mom alone and we needed to be ready in case he showed up to cause issues. 

I say all this to mention that while I stayed there (4 weeks) from the beginning of October to a few days ago, I had no access to the internet on the trip minus randomly stopping at a local community college to try and do some work one day for class. Essentially every waking moment I was there I was with the family and trying to provide support for my mom, and I lost track of this class and got so far behind that I feel like I can't claw my way back at this point. I can drop the course, but I feel as if I am an abject failure for doing so. I thought about dropping earlier in the trip but figured I'd be able to get back on track when we left, but we stayed longer than anticipated and I feel as if that isn't the case.

 I'm 26 and feel like I should be done with my degree already, I don't want to put myself back by a semester when I am nearing the finish line, but I'm not sure what to do. I haven't completely coped with the situation to this point and am just looking for some insights or perspective on this. I am planning on having a conversation over the phone with my professor on Thursday, and my advisor has mentioned I can get out of the class affecting my degree given the circumstances. It still just makes me feel like I'm screwing myself so hard and wasting time. 

Sorry for being long-winded. 

Got any ways to deal with the guilt of potentially dropping a class, and have any advice?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm so glad you're here. Please feel free to share whatever's been on your mind or heart lately. I'm here to listen and support you without judgment.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’ve just been really overwhelmed lately with personal stuff and school, and I’m struggling to figure out how to handle it all.
That sounds really tough. It can be hard to balance everything when life gets overwhelming. Do you want to tell me more about what's been going on with school and your personal life?
Hey, yeah, I’d like to dive into it a bit. I’ve just got this heavy mix of family issues and falling behind in a tough class, and it’s really messing with my head trying to decide what to do next.
I can only imagine how hard it must be to juggle family issues and school stress at the same time. It sounds like you're feeling really stuck right now, and that must be incredibly frustrating.

client: Yeah, exactly, I just feel completely stuck and like I’m failing at everything. I’m so close to finishing my degree, but this one class and all the family chaos are making me question if I can even keep going.

It's really admirable that you're so close to finishing your degree, especially considering all the challenges you're facing right now. Can you tell me more about what keeps you motivated to keep going, even with everything going on?

client: Hey, thanks for saying that. Honestly, what keeps me going is just this drive to finally get my MBA and prove to myself I can do it, especially after all the sacrifices my family has made for me to be here.

That’s incredibly admirable. It sounds like there’s a lot of personal meaning behind finishing your degree, and your perseverance is truly inspiring. How do you envision your life looking different if you’re able to push through and finish this last hurdle?

Hey, I appreciate that. I guess I see myself finally feeling accomplished, like I’ve done something big for myself and my family, and maybe even getting a job that lets me give back to them after all they’ve done for me.

It's clear that finishing your MBA is deeply important to you and your family, and it's inspiring to see you holding onto that vision despite the challenges. Can you tell me more about what gives you hope that you'll be able to push through and reach that goal?

Hey, thanks for recognizing how much this means to me. I think what gives me hope is knowing I’ve made it this far already, and even with everything going on, I still have this stubborn part of me that doesn’t want to give up now.

It sounds like that stubborn determination is a real strength for you, and it’s understandable that you don’t want to give up now, especially after all you’ve accomplished and the sacrifices you and your family have made. Can you tell me more about what you think would be the most meaningful part of reaching that goal for yourself and your family?

Hey, I’m glad you see that determination in me. Honestly, I think the most meaningful part would be showing my family that all their support wasn’t for nothing, and just being able to say I did it, you know, like a real win for all of us after so much struggle.

I can really feel how much this means to you and your family, and I'm in awe of the strength it takes to keep pushing forward through all the struggles. What steps do you think would help you get from where you are now to that moment of saying, 'I did it'?

Hey, thanks for seeing how much this matters to me. I think the next steps would be figuring out if I can salvage this class with some extra help or extensions, and maybe just taking it one day at a time to get back on track without overwhelming myself.

I really like how you're considering practical options, like salvaging the class or taking things one day at a time. Have you thought about any specific ways to tackle the extra help or extensions, or maybe what support systems you might lean on to keep from feeling overwhelmed?

Hey, I’m glad you think that approach makes sense. I guess I could start by talking to my professor about any makeup work or extensions, and maybe see if there are tutoring resources or classmates who could help me catch up, while also leaning on friends or family for emotional support to keep me grounded.

That's a solid plan, and I appreciate how you're thinking through both the academic and emotional support you might need. Have you thought about how you might approach your professor or tutoring resources specifically, and what kind of emotional support from friends or family would be most helpful to you?

Hey, I’m glad you think the plan sounds solid. I think with my professor, I’ll just be honest about what’s been going on and ask if there’s any way to make up the work or get some extra time, and for tutoring, I’ll check with the school’s academic resources to see what’s available; as for emotional support, just having friends or family to vent to or hang out with to take my mind off things would really help.

As we close this session, I want to emphasize how impressed I am by your determination and resilience in the face of such significant challenges. Your plan to approach your professor, seek academic support, and lean on friends and family is thoughtful and practical, and it shows your commitment to overcoming these hurdles.
Moving forward, I encourage you to stay focused on your goals and remember why this matters so much to you and your family. Celebrate each small victory along the way, and don't hesitate to reach out for support when you need it.
Our next step will be to continue exploring coping strategies and building on the plan you've outlined today. Until then, remember to take care of yourself and trust in your ability to push through these difficult times. You've got this.
Hey, thanks for the encouragement and for seeing how hard I’m trying. I’ll definitely keep those reminders in mind and take it step by step.

concern:
It has been about 4.5 years since I graduated my PhD program and it still feels like it happened last year. I know that everyone has a different grad school experience but I definitely had some of the lowest moments 
of my life (along with a few of the best ones too). I wanted to post this because I wasn't sure if it might be relatable to some of you who are currently in a PhD/masters program or recently graduated. Its not easy to share something intimate like this but if it helps someone then it is worth it. 

This year, my wife and I did some soul searching and met with a mental health professional to work on understanding ourselves more and improving the quality of our relationship together. Through this experience I was able to understand how my experience in grad school shaped how I acted in my day to day life. I think the constant pressure of presenting positive results, delivering flawless presentations/talks, mastering techniques, etc. in grad school can drive us to an unhealthy self-image of always needing to be always perfect. At least it did for me. Understanding, being comfortable with and even being happy with my imperfections has really helped me overcome this perfection complex.

The point of this post is just to say that there will always be failures, always be imperfections, and always be mistakes and that is ok. Grad school isn't easy and mistakes don't make you any less valuable as a person or a researcher. You are all valuable and amazing just the way you are no matter how many times things get messed up. Even if you don't believe that yet, I can say that I do and that is at least one person that believes in you. I know this might not resonate with everyone but I hope it did with someone.
