concern: As the title says my roommate doesn’t clean up after themself. Now our room isn’t a complete disaster and it’s mainly their side (plus our bathroom but it’s kinda 70/30 on who makes the most mess of it) but they just don’t really clean up. They have cups and cans and bottles all over their nightstand and desk and have even had a cup under their bed on the dresser before, and they’re never empty either. They also go home every weekend so they don’t really have dishes or real food here so they’re all Starbucks and Dunkin’ cups, so half full coffees just sitting there separating for weeks as they go home and come back. They do sorta clean it after a few weeks, I’ve seen them bag up the cups and other garbage, but they don’t take it out. They have bags full of garbage in the corner on their side of the room and our rooms not big so it’s starting to creep towards our closet almost in the way of it. As for the bathroom they leave hair everywhere and I know it’s theirs and not mine because it’s their little rubber bands with the hair. Now like I said I am also at fault for the the bathroom being messy but I try to keep it somewhat clean by taking out the garbage and have cleaned the shower drain but they don’t even try to clean up a bit. I don’t know how they don’t get embarrassed when they have a friend over or even just with me being here. I get embarrassed having 2 cans on my desk and a few dirty forks or spoons for a few days because I’m too tired to wash them yet. Otherwise they’re a good roommate it’s just they never clean. I should also say they had a single room last year so it definitely feels like part of the reason since they would be used to not sharing a space but I want to have friends over and I’m embarrassed for my roommate. I don’t really know how to tell them to take their garbage out without sounding like a bitch and I already accepted I’m gonna be cleaning our bathroom alone.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and support you, so feel free to share whatever is on your mind.
Hey, thanks for having me. I’m just really frustrated with my roommate situation and could use some advice on how to handle it without causing drama.

It sounds like you're feeling really stuck, and I can understand why. It's not easy to balance your own needs with maintaining a peaceful living environment. What's been happening with your roommate that's causing so much frustration?

Hey, yeah, it’s just been tough dealing with their lack of tidiness, you know? I’m worried about how it looks and feels in our shared space, and I’m not sure how to bring it up without starting a fight.

That must be really challenging for you. It's completely understandable that you'd feel frustrated and worried about the state of your shared space, especially when you're concerned about how to bring it up without causing tension. It sounds like you're caught between wanting to address the issue and not wanting to upset your roommate, which can be a really tricky spot to be in.

Yeah, exactly, I’m just torn because I don’t want to come off as naggy or create bad vibes, but it’s getting to me. I’m hoping we can figure out a way for me to talk about it that doesn’t make things weird between us.

I hear you, and it’s clear you care a lot about both your space and your relationship with your roommate. Let’s see if we can find a way to approach this that feels respectful and honest, without tipping the scales into drama. What would it look like for you if this conversation went well?

Honestly, if this conversation went well, I’d just want my roommate to hear me out and maybe start picking up after themselves a bit more without getting defensive. Like, I’d feel so relieved if we could just agree on some basic stuff to keep our space decent, you know?

That sounds like a really positive outcome, and I can understand why that would be such a relief for you. What do you think might happen if you could express your feelings and needs in a way that felt respectful and honest, without your roommate getting defensive?

I think if I could express myself clearly and calmly, there’s a chance they’d get where I’m coming from and be open to making a change. I just hope they don’t take it personally or shut down, ‘cause I really don’t want any tension in our space.

It's great that you can envision a positive outcome, and that you're thinking about how to approach this in a way that feels respectful and open to both of you. What do you think might help you feel more confident about starting that conversation, and staying calm if things get a little tricky?

I guess having a clear idea of what I want to say beforehand would help me feel more confident, like maybe jotting down a few points so I don’t ramble or get flustered. Also, just reminding myself to stay chill and focus on the issue, not them as a person, might keep things from getting heated if they push back a bit.

That sounds like a solid plan. Let's work on building those specific points you'd like to communicate, and I'll help you refine them to stay focused on the issue at hand. How would you feel about starting with a positive statement, like expressing appreciation for your roommate's presence in your life, before diving into the concerns?

Yeah, I think starting with something positive is a good idea, like telling them I appreciate how easygoing they are or something like that. It might set a better tone for the convo, you know, before I bring up the stuff that’s been bugging me.

Starting with something positive can definitely set a good tone for the conversation. Once you've acknowledged your roommate's positive qualities, you could transition into discussing the specific issues that have been bothering you. Remember to use ""I"" statements to express how you feel, rather than ""you"" statements that could come across as accusatory. For example, instead of saying ""You never clean up after yourself,"" you could say ""I feel frustrated when dishes are left in the sink overnight.""

Got it, using "I" statements makes a lot of sense to keep things from feeling like I’m attacking them. I’ll try something like, “I feel kinda stressed when there’s a lot of stuff piling up in our space,” so it’s more about how I’m feeling than pointing fingers.

That's a great way to frame it, and it's good that you're thinking about how to express your feelings without sounding accusatory. Now, let's think about how you might handle any potential pushback or defensiveness from your roommate. What strategies could you use to keep the conversation calm and productive if things start to get heated?

Honestly, if they get defensive, I think I’d just try to stay calm and not match their energy, like taking a deep breath and keeping my tone steady. Maybe I’d also say something like, “I just wanna work this out together,” to show I’m not trying to fight, just solve the issue.

Excellent, I think we've covered some really important ground here. Your plan to start with a positive statement, use "I" statements to express your concerns, and stay calm in the face of potential pushback is solid. Remember, the goal is to have a constructive conversation that leads to positive change, not to assign blame or escalate tensions.
To recap, here are your key goals and action steps:
1. Start with a positive statement to set a constructive tone for the conversation.
2. Use "I" statements to express your feelings and concerns, rather than "you" statements that could be perceived as accusatory.
3. Stay calm and composed during the conversation, even if your roommate becomes defensive or pushback occurs.
4. Offer solutions and suggestions for how to improve the situation, rather than simply stating the problem.
5. Be open to listening to your roommate's perspective and finding a compromise that works for both of you.
By following these steps, you should be able to have a productive conversation with your roommate and work towards finding a solution that addresses your concerns while also maintaining a positive relationship. Remember to take things one step at a time, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need further guidance or support. Good luck!
Thanks for breaking it down like that; it really helps to have a clear plan to follow. I’m feeling a bit more confident about tackling this convo now, so I’ll give it a shot soon and see how it goes.

client: Thanks for breaking it down like that; it really helps to have a clear plan to follow. I’m feeling a bit more confident about tackling this convo now, so I’ll give it a shot soon and see how it goes.

concern:
I’m reaching out because I’m facing a dilemma as I prepare to move to university in just four days. I need to decide whether to live in a dorm or to commute.

Here are the details:

Cost:
   - Dorming would cost around $40,000.
   - Commuting would cost around $20,000.

Program Participation: I’ve been accepted into a program called the RLC, which offers leadership opportunities and event planning experience. Being part of this program would enhance my transcript significantly, especially if I plan to transfer later. However, participation requires living on campus.

Personal Growth: I also want the opportunity to grow in a different environment, which living on campus could provide.

Location: I live only 10 minutes away from the university by car, making commuting a feasible option.

I’m feeling uncertain about which option is best for me and would greatly appreciate any advice you can offer.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. I'm all ears, and I want you to feel comfortable sharing whatever's on your mind. Is there something specific you'd like to talk about, or would you like to start wherever you feel is most important?
Hey, thanks for being here to listen. I’m just really torn about whether to live on campus or commute, and I’d like to dive into that since it’s been weighing on me a lot.
That sounds like a tough decision, and it's great that you're taking the time to think it through. What are some of the things that are making this choice so difficult for you?
Hey, yeah, it’s just really hard to weigh the pros and cons, you know? I’m worried about making the right call with so little time left to decide.

That's understandable. It sounds like you're feeling a lot of pressure to make the right decision, and that can be really stressful. Can you tell me more about what's weighing on your mind when you think about living on campus versus commuting?

Hey, yeah, it’s just this constant back-and-forth in my head about what I’m gaining or losing either way. I’m worried about missing out on stuff or making a choice I’ll regret, and it’s stressing me out with the deadline so close.

That back-and-forth can be exhausting, especially with a deadline looming. It sounds like you're caught between the idea of fully immersing yourself in campus life and the comforts of staying close to home. Do you feel like you're leaning toward one option more than the other, or does it still feel like a total toss-up?
Hey, honestly, it still feels like a total toss-up most of the time. I keep going in circles, and I’m just not sure which way to lean with everything on the line.

It sounds like you're really feeling the weight of this decision, and it's completely understandable that you're struggling to see a clear path forward. Have you considered exploring what your life might look like in a year if you choose one option versus the other, to see if that helps you visualize what feels more aligned with your goals and values?

Hey, yeah, I haven’t really thought about it that way, like picturing where I’d be a year from now with each choice. I guess I’ve been so stuck on the immediate stuff that looking ahead like that could maybe help me figure out what I really want.
That's a great insight! Let's see if we can unpack this a bit further. What would your ideal day look like in a year if you were living on campus versus commuting?

Hey, that’s a good question, and I’m kinda trying to picture it now. If I’m on campus, I see myself being super involved, like hanging out with friends after classes, doing events with that leadership program, and just feeling part of everything, but I worry about the cost dragging me down. If I’m commuting, I think my days would be more chill, saving money and sticking to a routine at home, but I’m scared I’d feel left out or like I’m missing the full college vibe. I guess I just don’t know which version of my future feels more “me.”

That's a really thoughtful reflection. It sounds like both options have their pros and cons. Can you tell me a bit more about what you mean by the “full college vibe” and why that feels important to you?

Hey, yeah, when I say “full college vibe,” I guess I mean just being immersed in that whole campus life, like staying up late talking with friends in the dorms, going to random events, and feeling like I’m really part of a community. It’s important to me because I don’t want to look back and feel like I missed out on those experiences, you know?

It sounds like the idea of being part of a campus community and having those spontaneous experiences really resonates with you. Let's see if we can explore that a bit further. On a scale of 0 to 10, how important is being immersed in that college vibe to you, and what would you say is the main reason it feels so crucial?

Hey, I’d probably rate it like an 8 or 9 out of 10, honestly, because I feel like college is this unique time to connect with people and grow in ways I can’t just by staying at home. The main reason it feels so crucial is that I’m worried if I don’t dive into that community now, I’ll regret it later and wonder what I could’ve gotten out of those experiences.

Based on your reflections, it seems like the importance of being immersed in campus life really centers around your desire for connection and growth. It sounds like you’re weighing the potential long-term impact of your decision, both in terms of personal fulfillment and future opportunities. As you consider the options, what steps do you think would help you feel more confident in your choice, whether that’s diving into the campus experience or creating a fulfilling routine at home?

Hey, that’s a good point to think about, and I guess I need to figure out some ways to make either choice feel right. Maybe I could talk to some people who’ve done both—dorming and commuting—to see how they handled it, and also look into if there’s any way to cut costs if I live on campus, like scholarships or part-time work. What do you think about starting there, or do you have any other ideas for figuring this out?

Based on what you've shared, exploring those options—talking to others who've done both and looking into cost-saving strategies—could give you valuable insights and help you feel more confident in your decision. It also aligns with your goal of balancing connection, growth, and practical considerations. Another idea might be to imagine what your ideal college experience would look like a year from now, and see which choice best supports that vision.

Hey, I like that idea of picturing where I want to be a year from now—it kinda helps put things into perspective. I’m just wondering, though, if I should also think about how each choice might affect stuff like my grades or stress levels, since I know dorming might come with distractions but commuting could feel isolating sometimes. What do you think about factoring that in too?

That’s a really thoughtful approach, and you're absolutely right to consider those factors—grades and stress levels are important to think about. Reflecting on how each option might affect your academic performance and emotional well-being could help you create a more balanced plan. For example, if you choose to live on campus, maybe you could explore ways to manage potential distractions, like setting aside dedicated study time or finding a quiet workspace. If you decide to commute, perhaps you could think about ways to stay connected to the campus community, like joining clubs or attending events. It sounds like you're already thinking about how to mitigate any potential downsides, which is a great sign that you're on the right track.

Hey, thanks for breaking it down like that—it really helps to think about managing distractions or staying connected if I commute. I guess I just need to figure out how realistic those strategies are for me, you know, like if I can actually stick to a study schedule in a dorm or make time for campus stuff while living at home. What do you think would be a good way to test out how I’d handle either situation before fully committing?

Based on your thoughtful reflections, one idea could be to create a trial period where you test out aspects of each option. For example, you might spend a weekend living on campus to see how you manage distractions and study time, or commit to attending a few campus events while living at home to gauge your ability to stay connected. This could give you a sense of what feels most realistic and sustainable for you, while also helping you identify potential barriers to address. It’s all about finding a balance that aligns with your goals and priorities, and it sounds like you’re already thinking through those considerations in a really thoughtful way.

Hey, I really like the idea of doing a trial period to get a feel for both options. I’m just not sure how feasible it is to spend a weekend on campus before I’ve made a decision—do you think there’s another way to kinda simulate that dorm experience or test out my ability to balance things while commuting?

Sure thing, let’s think this through! How about we consider a few different options to simulate both the dorm experience and the commute? One idea could be to spend a weekend at a friend’s place who lives on campus, or even a family member’s home near the university, to get a sense of what it’s like to be in that environment. Another option might be to visit campus for a day and attend a few classes or events, then spend the evening at a local café or library to see how you’d handle studying away from home. On the flip side, if you’re leaning towards commuting, you could try attending a few events on campus during the week and then heading back home, to get a sense of how that balance might feel.

Hey, those are some cool ideas to get a sense of both setups without fully committing yet. I’m a bit worried about whether a short visit will really show me the full picture, but I’m willing to give it a shot and see how it feels.

concern: How do you make friends in college? I graduated hs recently and I didn’t have friends in hs so I’m not the best at socializing. I start next month and I really want to make friends and have a good time but I don’t know how people are here 😭 I’m just really nervous about even walking into class and finding a seat..

dialogue_total.statement: Hello, and welcome! I'm here to listen and help in any way I can. Feel free to share whatever's on your mind—I'm all ears and ready to support you.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just really nervous about starting college next month and figuring out how to make friends since I didn’t have any in high school.
It's totally normal to feel nervous about starting college, especially when it comes to making friends. Can you tell me more about what you're worried about?

Yeah, I guess I’m just worried about not knowing how to even start a conversation or fit in with people. It feels like everyone else already knows what they’re doing, and I’m just gonna be super awkward or out of place.

You seem to feel a bit overwhelmed about starting college and making friends, especially with the fear of feeling awkward or out of place. That's completely understandable, and I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can.
Thanks, I really appreciate that. I just keep thinking I’ll mess up somehow, like say the wrong thing or not know how to act around new people.

It sounds like you’re really worried about making a mistake and not knowing how to interact with new people, which is making you feel anxious and unsure about starting college. Can you tell me more about what you think might happen if you do say the wrong thing or don’t know how to act?

Honestly, I’m scared that if I say something dumb or act weird, people will just judge me or not want to talk to me at all. I feel like I’ll end up alone again, like I was in high school, and that thought just kinda freaks me out.

It sounds like you're really worried about making a mistake and not knowing how to interact with new people, which is making you feel anxious and unsure about starting college. Can you tell me more about what you think might happen if you do say the wrong thing or don't know how to act?

Yeah, I just keep imagining that if I mess up, people will think I’m weird or just not worth getting to know. It’s like I’ll be stuck on my own again, and I really don’t want to go through that feeling of being left out all over.

I hear how much you want to connect with others and avoid feeling left out, and that fear of being judged is really holding you back. What if we explored ways you could start small, like just introducing yourself to one person in your class or joining a club that interests you, to see how things go and maybe build some confidence before diving in fully?
That sounds like a good idea, but I’m still kinda nervous about even starting with just one person or a club. I mean, what if I don’t know what to say or they don’t seem interested in talking to me?

I understand that starting with even just one person or a club can still feel daunting, but it might help to focus on small steps that feel manageable. What if you thought of a few simple icebreaker questions you could ask others, like how they like the class or their favorite hobby? That way, you could start conversations without feeling like you need to be the one talking the whole time.

Yeah, I like the idea of having some go-to questions to break the ice, but I still worry I’ll freeze up or sound super awkward when I ask them. I guess I just don’t trust myself to not mess it up, you know?

It's completely understandable that you're worried about feeling awkward, but remember that everyone gets nervous sometimes. Even if you do freeze up or stumble over your words, you could reframe that moment as a chance to show others that you're human and relatable. And hey, what if you practiced asking those icebreaker questions in front of a mirror or with a trusted friend? That might help you feel more comfortable and confident when the time comes.

Yeah, practicing in front of a mirror or with someone I trust could help, I think, just to get the hang of it without the pressure. I’m just kinda scared that even with practice, I’ll still come off as weird or out of place when I actually try it in real life, you know?

That fear of not fitting in is totally valid, but what if you reminded yourself that being a little different isn't a bad thing? People are often drawn to others who are genuine and authentic, even if they don't always fit the mold. Plus, you might be surprised by how many others feel just as nervous as you do in social situations.

Yeah, I get that being genuine matters, but I still can’t shake the feeling that people might just see me as awkward instead of authentic. It’s like, I want to connect, but I’m so worried I’ll mess up that first impression, you know?

It's natural to want to make a good impression, but what if you shifted your focus from trying to be perfect to just being present and curious about others? That way, even if you stumble a bit, your genuine interest in connecting could shine through and help others see beyond any initial awkwardness.

Yeah, I like the idea of focusing on being curious about others instead of stressing over being perfect. It’s just hard to imagine that working when I’m already overthinking every little thing I say, you know?

I hear you, and it's understandable that old habits can be hard to break. Maybe you could try setting a small intention for yourself before entering a social situation, like asking one person a question about their interests, and then let go of the rest. Remember, the goal isn't to be perfect, but to be present and genuinely curious. And hey, if you do overthink things, you could even acknowledge it playfully with something like, ""Oops, I'm doing it again!"" to help lighten the moment.

Yeah, setting a small goal like asking one question sounds doable, and I think it might take some of the pressure off. I’m just still kinda worried that even with that, I’ll freeze up or say something dumb, you know?

Let's summarize your goals and action steps for our next session. We discussed the importance of focusing on being present and genuinely curious when engaging in social interactions, rather than striving for perfection. To help you achieve this, we agreed on setting a small intention before entering social situations, such as asking one person a question about their interests. We also discussed acknowledging overthinking moments playfully to help lighten the situation.
For your next steps, practice setting small intentions for social interactions and remember that the goal is to be present and genuinely curious. Try to reframe your thinking by reminding yourself that being different isn't a bad thing and that others may feel just as nervous as you do. Lastly, don't forget to be kind to yourself and acknowledge that it's okay to make mistakes.
Remember, it's all about taking small steps towards your goals, and I'm here to support you along the way. Let's continue to work on these strategies in our next session.

Thanks for summarizing everything, I really appreciate the reminder to take small steps and be kind to myself. I’m still a bit nervous about putting this into practice, but I’ll give it a shot and see how it feels.

concern: I’m feeling nervous about college and debating if i’ve picked the right one. I’m already registered for classes and I have my dorm room/roomate all set but I can’t help but feel nervous. Does/Did anyone feel this way? I’m very introverted and I feel like I won’t be able to make friends because I’m just awkward.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm so glad you're here today. Feel free to share anything on your mind, whether it's a concern, a thought, or even just something you'd like to chat about. I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. 😊

Hey, thanks for being here to talk. I’ve just been feeling really nervous about starting college and whether I made the right choice, and I’m kinda worried about fitting in since I’m pretty introverted.

That sounds really stressful, especially when you're already feeling uncertain about your decision. It's understandable that you're worried about fitting in, but remember that being introverted doesn't mean you won't make friends. It just means you might need to find people who appreciate your quieter nature.
Thanks, that makes me feel a bit better to hear. I just keep overthinking everything, ya know, like whether I’ll even click with anyone or if I’ll just end up feeling out of place all the time.

That's a lot to process all at once, and it's natural to feel anxious about the unknown. But remember, you don't have to have everything figured out right away. Let's talk about what you're hoping to get out of college and what your ideal social circle would look like.

Yeah, I guess I’m just hoping college will be a place where I can grow and figure out who I am, ya know? I’d love to have a small group of close friends who get me, but I’m not even sure how to start finding them.

It sounds like you have a good idea of what you're hoping to get out of college, both academically and socially. You mentioned wanting a small group of close friends who understand you, which is a great goal. Have you thought about any specific ways you might start finding those people, like joining clubs or organizations that align with your interests?

Yeah, I’ve thought about maybe joining a club or something, but I get kinda anxious just thinking about putting myself out there. I’m not sure I’d even know how to start a convo or if I’d feel weird being in a new group.

It's great that you're thinking about joining a club or organization. While it's natural to feel anxious about starting conversations in a new group, remember that everyone there is likely feeling the same way. What if you start by observing and listening for a bit, and then look for opportunities to contribute to the conversation when you feel comfortable? And if you're feeling overwhelmed, it's always okay to take a break and step outside for a moment to collect your thoughts.
Yeah, I like the idea of just observing at first, that feels less intimidating. I guess I’m just worried I’ll still feel out of place or like I don’t belong even after trying, ya know?

It's totally understandable to feel like you might not fit in right away, but remember that building connections takes time and effort. It's okay to start small and focus on one or two people you feel comfortable with. What are some things you think would make you feel more at ease in a new group?

Hmm, I think maybe if I could find people who share some of my interests, like books or movies, that’d help me feel more at ease. I just don’t know how to spot those people or bring it up without feeling super awkward about it.

That's a great point, sharing common interests can be a great way to connect with others. One idea could be to look for clubs or groups that focus on books or movies, like a book club or a film appreciation group. You could also try asking people about their interests in a casual way, like mentioning a book or movie you've enjoyed and seeing if anyone else has an opinion on it. It's all about taking small steps and finding opportunities to engage with others in a way that feels comfortable for you.

Yeah, that makes sense, starting with a club that’s already about something I like could take some of the pressure off. I’m just kinda nervous about even walking into one of those meetings and figuring out how to jump into a convo without feeling like I’m forcing it.

It's completely normal to feel that way, especially when stepping into an unfamiliar environment. You could try arriving a few minutes early to the meeting, so you have some time to observe the group dynamic before fully joining in. Remember, you don't have to jump into a conversation right away. Take your time, listen, and when you feel ready, you could try asking someone a question about the book or movie being discussed, or share a thought you have.
Thanks, that’s a good tip about getting there early to kinda scope things out. I just hope I don’t freeze up when it’s time to actually say something, ya know?

That's completely understandable, and it's great that you're thinking ahead. You could try practicing what you might say beforehand, or even writing down some conversation starters to help you feel more prepared. Remember, it's okay to take your time and speak when you feel comfortable.

Yeah, I like the idea of practicing a bit before I go, maybe just running through a couple things I could mention about a book or movie. It’s just tough ‘cause I overthink stuff and end up worrying I’ll sound dumb or out of place, ya know?

I understand how daunting it can feel to step out of your comfort zone, especially when you're worried about sounding awkward or out of place. But remember, everyone else in that room is probably feeling a little nervous too, and they're all there for the same reason: to connect over a shared interest. By preparing a few conversation starters and taking your time to observe the group dynamic, you'll be giving yourself the best chance to ease into the situation without feeling overwhelmed.

Thanks for reminding me that I’m not the only one who might be nervous—it helps to think of it that way. I’ll definitely try to keep those tips in mind and not put too much pressure on myself. So, um, do you think it’s worth checking out a couple different clubs to see which one feels like the best fit, or should I just stick to one for now?

Great question! It's a good idea to explore a few clubs to see which ones resonate with you and your interests. That way, you can get a sense of the different group dynamics and find a community where you feel comfortable and supported. Remember, it's okay to take your time and try out a few different options before committing to one. And don't forget to keep those conversation starters handy and practice them beforehand to help ease any nerves you might feel. You've got this!

Thanks, I appreciate the encouragement to check out a few options without rushing to decide. So, uh, I guess I’ll start by looking up some meeting times this week and see what’s out there—do you think just showing up to watch at first is okay, or should I try to jump in right away?

concern:
Hi I’m 18 m turning 19 in august and I have to make a choice about college. I have been accepted into my 3rd and 4th choice colleges and I now need to decide if I am gonna take another gap year or go to college this fall.

I would like to go to college as soon as possible but I really want to try and get in to my 1st or 2nd choice schools as they are both 80,000$ cheaper then the other 2 and in a better location
I plan to go for aviation/flight management to be a pilot at all schools 

I am worried about staying another year as all my friends are going to college this year and I would really like to move out and live on my own also I fear I might not get accepted next year if I stay

For the cost my parents have set aside enough money to afford the 80,000$ schools but I feel bad making them spend that much when I could try to get into a far cheaper and better school 

The best schools for my program are my 1st and 2nd choice schools the (cheaper ones)

Also I am in Ontario Canada and all the schools are also in Ontario Canada if it matters 

Hope this all made sense all advice is appreciated 
If you have any questions please ask 

Thanks again

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm so glad you're here today. I'd love to hear whatever's on your mind, whether it's something specific that's been weighing on you or just a general feeling you'd like to explore.
Hey, thanks for having me. I’m just really torn about this college decision and could use some help figuring out what to do.
That sounds really tough - college decisions are such a big deal. I'd love to hear more about what's got you feeling torn.
Hey, yeah, it’s just a lot to think about, you know? I’m stuck between wanting to start college now and waiting to maybe get into a better, cheaper school next year.

You're caught between the excitement of diving in right away and the potential benefits of waiting for a better fit. That must feel really overwhelming, like you're balancing two opposing ideas. Can you tell me more about what makes each option so tempting?

Hey, yeah, it’s definitely overwhelming trying to weigh both sides. Like, starting now feels exciting because I’d finally be on my own and moving forward, but waiting could mean a school that’s a better match and way less of a financial burden.

I can hear how much you want to make the right choice for yourself, and how much you care about your future. Both options seem to hold so much potential, and it's understandable that you're feeling stuck. Can you help me understand what's most important to you in this decision, and what you might regret more later on?

Hey, yeah, I think what’s most important to me is getting into a program that’s the best fit for what I want to do, you know, without putting too much stress on my family financially. I guess I’d regret more if I rushed into a school now and then felt like I missed out on a better opportunity—or if I wait and don’t get in anywhere better next year, that’d suck too.

It sounds like you're really wrestling with two strong priorities: finding the best fit for your goals and being mindful of the financial impact on your family. Both of those regrets you mentioned highlight how much you care about making a thoughtful choice, even though it’s not easy.

Hey, yeah, it’s definitely a tough spot to be in, trying to balance what’s best for me and not wanting to burden my family. I just keep going back and forth on whether the risk of waiting is worth it, you know?

It's clear that you're deeply invested in finding a solution that honors both your own aspirations and your family's well-being. Perhaps reflecting on what a 'best fit' program truly means to you—both academically and personally—could help clarify whether the potential benefits of waiting outweigh the excitement of starting now. How do you imagine your ideal program aligning with your goals and values?

Hey, yeah, I think my ideal program would be one that’s got a really strong reputation for aviation and flight management, and gives me the best shot at becoming a pilot with good job prospects. It’d also be in a location I vibe with, and honestly, not costing my parents an arm and a leg would make me feel a lot better about the whole thing.

It sounds like your ideal program is a perfect blend of academic excellence, career opportunities, and personal well-being. I can see how important it is for you to find a program that aligns with your passion for aviation and your values of financial responsibility. How do you feel about the potential of finding a program that meets these criteria, and how do you envision it impacting your life in the long run?

Hey, I think finding a program that checks all those boxes would be amazing, like it’d set me up for a career I’m passionate about without all the guilt of the cost. I can see it making a huge difference long-term, you know, giving me confidence in my skills and not stressing about debt or feeling like I let my family down.

That's a powerful vision you have there, and I can sense the relief and confidence that comes with it. Let's explore some actionable steps you could take to start moving toward this ideal program—perhaps researching schools that meet your criteria, reaching out to alumni for insights, or even discussing potential financial arrangements with your parents. What steps feel most manageable or exciting to you right now?

Hey, I think starting with some research on schools that fit what I’m looking for sounds doable, like digging into their aviation programs and seeing what kind of feedback they get from students or grads. Also, maybe chatting with alumni could be cool to get a real sense of what it’s like, you know?

That sounds like a solid plan—researching schools and gathering firsthand insights from alumni could give you a clearer picture of which programs align best with your goals. Would you like to outline specific steps for this research phase, or perhaps discuss how to approach those conversations with alumni in a way that feels natural and productive for you?

Hey, yeah, I think outlining some specific steps for the research part would be really helpful, just to keep me on track and make sure I’m not missing anything important. Like, maybe figuring out what exactly to look for in the programs or how to organize all the info I find—do you have any tips on that?

It's great to hear you're excited to start researching schools and gathering insights from alumni! Let's break this down into manageable steps. First, we could create a list of key factors you want to look for in aviation programs, such as curriculum, internship opportunities, or cost. Next, we could explore ways to organize the information you find, like using a spreadsheet or note-taking app to keep track of pros and cons for each school. What do you think would work best for you?

Hey, I think making a list of key factors like curriculum and cost is a great starting point, and using a spreadsheet to organize everything sounds super practical. What kind of specific things should I prioritize in the list, or like, how detailed should I get with it to make sure I’m covering all the bases?

Great to hear you're excited about starting your research! Let's build on that momentum by creating a comprehensive list of key factors that align with your goals and priorities. Here are some suggestions to consider:
1. Curriculum: Look for programs that offer a strong focus on aviation, with courses that align with your interests and career aspirations.
2. Cost: Consider tuition fees, scholarships, and financial aid options to ensure the program is affordable for you and your family.
3. Internship and job opportunities: Research the school's connections with aviation companies and the success rate of graduates in securing jobs in the industry.
4. Alumni network: Investigate the strength of the school's alumni network and how it can benefit you in terms of mentorship, job opportunities, and professional connections.
5. Location and campus life: Consider the school's location, campus facilities, and extracurricular activities that might enhance your overall college experience.
6. Accreditation and reputation: Ensure the school is accredited by a recognized accrediting agency and has a strong reputation in the aviation industry.
For your spreadsheet, you could create columns for each of these factors and rate each school based on how well they meet your criteria. This will help you visualize the pros and cons of each program and make a more informed

Hey, thanks for laying out those factors—they all make a lot of sense and give me a good framework to start with. I’m feeling a bit overwhelmed with how much there is to consider, so maybe we can talk about how to narrow it down or focus on what’s most important to me right now?

Sure thing, let's tackle that! It's understandable to feel overwhelmed with all these factors to consider. To help you focus on what's most important right now, let's start by identifying your top priorities. Which of these factors do you feel are the most crucial to your decision? For example, is cost the biggest concern for you, or are you more focused on finding a program with strong job prospects in the aviation industry? Once we have a clearer picture of your priorities, we can narrow down your options and create a more manageable plan.
Hey, I appreciate you helping me narrow this down. I think cost and job prospects are probably the biggest things for me right now—can we dive a bit deeper into how to weigh those against each other?

concern:
Hey all! I saw that people can help. So I’m going to try this too!

I am 24 and still in college. I started in 2016 and took some time off to battle depression. Although it was tough, I won eventually. I decided to go back in 2021 and I have been doing well until now. I find myself questioning the reason I’m here all the time. I don’t know what my ‘Why’ or my true purpose is. I don’t care about being my age in college because how others view me doesn’t matter. I believe that I will finish, I think? If I were not in college, I don’t know what I would be doing with myself but working at a soul sucking job. I am having trouble matching actions with my words and thoughts. I haven’t been studying consistently and I sometimes avoid classes. I am on academic probation again and I just don’t understand why I continue to self sabotage when I claim that I am confident and want to be a college graduate. 

I even try to better myself with reading self-help books, talking to my support system, and be more outgoing on campus like joining clubs and going to parties. Parties are played out to me and the clubs are going okay. Atomic habits, reinventing the habit wheel, and meditation have all helped me in short bursts, but I still am having trouble getting my sh*t together. I am starting to feel hopeless. I don’t want to feel hopeless ever again. Last time I felt that way I was deeply depressed. I want to be better than this. How can fight against my negative emotions? How can be more consistent with the things that will better myself? How can I win the war against my mind and body? Any suggestions please?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and help you explore your thoughts and feelings. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind, and know that you're in a safe and non-judgmental space.

Thanks for having me, I really appreciate having this space to talk. I’ve just been feeling so lost lately with school and figuring out my purpose, and I’m kinda scared I’m slipping back into old patterns.
It sounds like you're carrying a lot of weight right now, and it's okay to feel that way. You're not alone in this journey, and I'm here to listen and support you without judgment.

Thanks, I’m glad to hear that. I just don’t know how to keep pushing forward when I feel so stuck, you know? Like, I want to do better, but I keep messing up and I’m scared of falling back into that dark place again. How do I even start to get a grip on this?

It's completely understandable to feel stuck and overwhelmed, especially when you're facing multiple challenges at once. Remember that you've made it through difficult times before, and that strength is still within you. Take things one step at a time, and don't be too hard on yourself when you stumble - every step forward, no matter how small, is still progress.

Thanks for saying that, it helps to hear I’ve got some strength in me even if I don’t always feel it. I just wish I could figure out how to take those small steps without tripping over myself every other day, you know? Like, I’ll start something good, like studying or sticking to a routine, but then I just… stop. How do I keep that momentum going when my mind keeps pulling me back?

It's like your mind is pulling you in different directions, and it can be really tough to stay on track when you're feeling that internal conflict. Let's try to break this down a bit - what do you think might be some of the things that are making it hard for you to keep that momentum going?

Honestly, I think it’s a mix of just feeling overwhelmed and doubting myself all the time. Like, I start something and then my brain just goes, “Why even bother, you’re gonna fail anyway,” and I end up giving up before I even really try. How do I stop those thoughts from taking over every time I wanna push forward?

It sounds like those negative thoughts are really holding you back and making it hard for you to believe in yourself. Let's see if we can explore some ways to help you quiet those thoughts and build up your confidence. What do you think might happen if you could find a way to push through those doubts and keep moving forward, even when it's hard?

I think if I could push through those doubts, I might actually start to see some real progress and feel better about myself, you know? Like, maybe I’d finally get that sense of accomplishment I’ve been chasing, but it just feels so far out of reach right now. How do I even start to believe I can do it when I’ve messed up so many times before?

You've already taken an important step by acknowledging those negative thoughts and wanting to push through them. Let's try to focus on the present moment and what you can do right now, rather than dwelling on past setbacks. What would be one small, achievable action you could take today that would help you feel like you're moving forward?

Honestly, I guess I could just commit to sitting down for like 30 minutes to review my notes or something small like that. It doesn’t sound like much, but maybe starting there could help me feel like I’m at least doing *something*, you know? What do you think—does that sound like a decent starting point, or should I aim for something else?

I think that sounds like a great starting point! Setting aside 30 minutes to review your notes is a manageable and achievable action that can help you build momentum and start feeling like you're making progress. Let's focus on that as your first step, and we can revisit it together to see how it goes and make adjustments as needed.

Cool, I’m glad you think it’s a good idea. I’ll give it a shot today and see how it feels, even if I’m kinda nervous I’ll just zone out or something. How do I keep myself from getting distracted or letting those dumb negative thoughts creep in while I’m trying to focus?

That’s a really good question, and it’s natural to worry about distractions or negative thoughts popping up. One thing you could try is setting a specific goal for those 30 minutes—like focusing on a single topic or section of your notes—so you have a clear direction to keep your mind on track. You could also try placing your phone or other distractions out of reach during that time, or maybe even reward yourself with something small afterward to stay motivated.

Hey, that makes sense, I like the idea of having a clear focus for those 30 minutes and getting rid of distractions like my phone. I’ll try picking one topic to dive into and maybe set a little reward like grabbing a coffee after—hopefully that’ll keep me going without those negative thoughts sneaking in. How do I handle it if I still end up feeling stuck or like I’m not getting anywhere during that time?

That’s a great question, and it’s good to think ahead. If you find yourself feeling stuck during those 30 minutes, try taking a brief pause and reminding yourself that it’s okay to feel this way sometimes—progress isn’t always linear. You could also jot down any thoughts or questions that come up, even if they seem unclear, and revisit them later with a fresh perspective. And if you’re still feeling stuck after the 30 minutes, we can explore other strategies together, like breaking the task into smaller chunks or identifying specific obstacles to address.

Hey, I appreciate that—it’s kinda relieving to hear that it’s okay to feel stuck sometimes. I’ll try taking that pause if I need to and jotting down whatever’s in my head, even if it feels messy. Do you think it’d help to, like, set a timer for a quick break if I’m really struggling, so I don’t just give up completely? I don’t wanna lose the whole 30 minutes, you know?

You’ve got this! I think that’s a fantastic idea, and it’s great that you’re thinking ahead about ways to stay on track. Setting a timer for a quick break if you’re struggling is a smart move—it can help you reset and come back to your task with renewed focus without getting discouraged. Remember, it’s all about progress, not perfection. And if you do end up taking a break, don’t forget to reward yourself afterwards—that coffee you mentioned sounds like a great incentive to keep you motivated. Keep in mind, you can always reach out to me if you need additional support or guidance along the way.

Hey, thanks for the encouragement, it really helps to hear that. I’ll set that timer for a short break if I need it and keep that coffee reward in mind to push through. I’m feeling a bit better about trying this out—do you think we could check in next week to see how it’s going?

Like, maybe I’d finally get that sense of accomplishment I’ve been chasing, but it just feels so far out of reach right now. How do I even start to believe I can do it when I’ve messed up so many times before?
therapist: You've already taken an important step by acknowledging those negative thoughts and wanting to push through them. Let's try to focus on the present moment and what you can do right now, rather than dwelling on past setbacks. What would be one small, achievable action you could take today that would help you feel like you're moving forward?
client: Honestly, I guess I could just commit to sitting down for like 30 minutes to review my notes or something small like that. It doesn’t sound like much, but maybe starting there could help me feel like I’m at least doing *something*, you know? What do you think—does that sound like a decent starting point, or should I aim for something else?
therapist: I think that sounds like a great starting point! Setting aside 30 minutes to review your notes is a manageable and achievable action that can help you build momentum and start feeling like you're making progress. Let's focus on that as your first step, and we can revisit it together to see how it goes and make adjustments as needed.
client: Cool, I’m glad you think it’s a good idea. I’ll give it a shot today and see how it feels, even if I’m kinda nervous I’ll just zone out or something. How do I keep myself from getting distracted or letting those dumb negative thoughts creep in while I’m trying to focus?
therapist: That’s a really good question, and it’s natural to worry about distractions or negative thoughts popping up. One thing you could try is setting a specific goal for those 30 minutes—like focusing on a single topic or section of your notes—so you have a clear direction to keep your mind on track. You could also try placing your phone or other distractions out of reach during that time, or maybe even reward yourself with something small afterward to stay motivated.
client: Hey, that makes sense, I like the idea of having a clear focus for those 30 minutes and getting rid of distractions like my phone. I’ll try picking one topic to dive into and maybe set a little reward like grabbing a coffee after—hopefully that’ll keep me going without those negative thoughts sneaking in. How do I handle it if I still end up feeling stuck or like I’m not getting anywhere during that time?
therapist: That’s a great question, and it’s good to think ahead. If you find yourself feeling stuck during those 30 minutes, try taking a brief pause and reminding yourself that it’s okay to feel this way sometimes—progress isn’t always linear. You could also jot down any thoughts or questions that come up, even if they seem unclear, and revisit them later with a fresh perspective. And if you’re still feeling stuck after the 30 minutes, we can explore other strategies together, like breaking the task into smaller chunks or identifying specific obstacles to address.
client: Hey, I appreciate that—it’s kinda relieving to hear that it’s okay to feel stuck sometimes. I’ll try taking that pause if I need to and jotting down whatever’s in my head, even if it feels messy. Do you think it’d help to, like, set a timer for a quick break if I’m really struggling, so I don’t just give up completely? I don’t wanna lose the whole 30 minutes, you know?
therapist: You’ve got this! I think that’s a fantastic idea, and it’s great that you’re thinking ahead about ways to stay on track. Setting a timer for a quick break if you’re struggling is a smart move—it can help you reset and come back to your task with renewed focus without getting discouraged. Remember, it’s all about progress, not perfection. And if you do end up taking a break, don’t forget to reward yourself afterwards—that coffee you mentioned sounds like a great incentive to keep you motivated. Keep in mind, you can always reach out to me if you need additional support or guidance along the way.
client: Hey, thanks for the encouragement, it really helps to hear that. I’ll set that timer for a short break if I need it and keep that coffee reward in mind to push through. I’m feeling a bit better about trying this out—do you think we could check in next week to see how it’s going?

concern:
Hello,

It's true that this begins with a mistake of mine but my degree supervisors ended up insulting me, saying I had psychological problems, reaching the point Godwin and denying the fact that I had a physical disability.

It's someone I so immensely trusted and was so grateful to. I hoped to work with them in the future and worked more in their subjects where I had the best grades.

These persons are now less rude against me but I feel so bad about this, I am so deeply hurt and I can't focus on my lectures with them anymore without thinking about what happened.

These persons are the one who gave me interest in the degree I'm pursuing and I'm not even feeling good about my own degree anymore, I'me even doubting my career.

I am old for my cohort as I had a lot of issues in the past with my disability and health and these people are the one who gave me a second chance and now it went like this. I don't think I can change to another degree or start over. But it hurts me to continue. I have only these persons in lectures now, and I feel bad spending 20h a week with them and working on their things and so on.

I'm absolutely lost, I don't know what to do. I fear reaching out, I fear telling them how I feel about what happened, I feel like giving up.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session! I'm here to listen and support you, so please feel free to share whatever's on your mind.
Thanks for being here. I’m just feeling really overwhelmed and hurt by some stuff that’s happened with my degree supervisors, and it’s messing with my head a lot.

It sounds like you're going through a really tough time with your supervisors, and it's completely understandable that you'd feel overwhelmed and hurt. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been going on?
Yeah, it’s just been a rough situation that’s left me feeling really betrayed and down. I’m struggling to even focus on my studies now because of it.

It's clear that this situation has had a significant impact on your well-being and academic focus. I can imagine how difficult it must be to feel betrayed and overwhelmed by the people who are supposed to support you. Would you feel comfortable sharing more about what specifically has happened with your supervisors?
Honestly, I’m not sure if I’m ready to dive into all the details just yet, it’s still pretty raw. I just feel so stuck and don’t know how to move forward with everything weighing on me like this.

I completely understand, and there's no rush to share more than you're comfortable with right now. It's important to acknowledge that you're feeling stuck and weighed down, and I'm here to support you in finding a way forward. Let's take it one step at a time, and focus on what feels manageable for you.
Yeah, I appreciate that, I really do. I guess I just need to figure out how to deal with being around them so much without feeling like I’m crumbling inside every time.

It sounds like you're trying to find a way to navigate these difficult interactions without letting them consume your emotions. It's a tough balance, but I'm curious, have you noticed any moments when you felt a bit more in control or grounded in these situations?
Yeah, not really, honestly. It’s like every time I’m in their lectures or working on their stuff, it just hits me all over again and I feel so out of place, like I don’t even belong there.

I can sense the weight of those emotions, and it's understandable that it feels overwhelming to be in those situations. I'm curious, what would it look like for you to feel like you belong there again?

I don’t even know if that’s possible anymore, to be honest. Like, I keep thinking about how things used to be and how much I looked up to them, and now it’s just this big mess in my head that I can’t shake.

I can see how those memories and feelings of respect are tangled up with the present challenges, creating a heavy emotional knot. Let's explore this idea of feeling like you belong again - even if it seems impossible now, can you imagine what one small step towards that feeling might look like?

I guess maybe just being able to sit in their class without overthinking every word they say would be a start. It’s hard to picture even that, though, when I’m just stuck feeling so hurt and outta place all the time.

It sounds like even a small shift, like being able to sit in class without overthinking, would make a big difference for you. I'm curious, what might it take for you to feel just a little more grounded in that moment, even if it's not a complete solution?

I think maybe just focusing on something else during class, like taking notes or really zoning in on the material, could help me not spiral so much. It’s tough though, ‘cause my mind just keeps wandering back to everything that’s happened, and I don’t know how to stop it.

It's interesting that you've already identified a potential strategy for staying grounded, like focusing on the material or taking notes. That shows you have some insight into what could help. If you were to try that in class, how do you think it might shift your experience, even if just a little?

I think it might help me feel a bit less overwhelmed, like I’m actually doing something productive instead of just sitting there stuck in my head. I’m not sure if it’ll fully stop the thoughts, but maybe it could at least give me a little break from them for a while.

That's a really thoughtful approach you've described, and it's encouraging to hear that you're open to trying it out. It sounds like even a brief reprieve from those intrusive thoughts could make a meaningful difference in how you experience class. I'm curious, what would it feel like for you to have that small break, even if it's just for a few moments?

I think it would feel like a tiny bit of relief, honestly, like I could breathe a little easier for those few minutes. It wouldn’t fix everything, but just having a moment where I’m not drowning in those feelings would be something, ya know?

It's great to hear that even a small moment of relief could be so meaningful for you. What would it take for you to actually try out this strategy in class, and how might you remind yourself to focus on taking notes or engaging with the material when your mind starts to wander?

I guess it would take just pushing myself to start, like making a conscious effort to pick up my pen or really listen to what’s being said. Maybe I could set a little reminder, like a sticky note on my notebook that says ‘focus’ or something, to snap me back if I start drifting off.

That sounds like a solid plan, and the sticky note idea could be a helpful visual cue. If you do try it out, what would be a way for you to acknowledge and celebrate even the smallest success, like managing to focus for a few minutes?

I think just noticing that I managed to stay on track for a bit would feel good, like giving myself a mental pat on the back. Maybe I could even jot down a quick note about it after class to kinda remind myself I did something positive, ya know?

That sounds like a thoughtful way to acknowledge your progress, and writing down those moments of focus could help you track your successes over time. What might be a few specific situations where you could try out this strategy first, to test the waters and build some confidence in its effectiveness?

I think I could start with the shorter lectures or maybe the ones where I feel a tiny bit less overwhelmed, just to ease into it. Like, there’s this one class that’s not as intense, so maybe trying it there first would be a good way to test it out, ya know?

Great, it sounds like you've got a clear plan in place. Remember to celebrate your successes, no matter how small they may seem, and to continue building on your progress. It's all about taking things one step at a time and being patient with yourself. You've got this! And don't forget, if you need any further support, I'm always here to help.
Thanks, I really appreciate the encouragement and knowing I can reach out if I need to. I’ll give it a shot in that class and see how it feels, just taking it slow like you said.

As we wrap up today's session, let's take a moment to reflect on the progress we've made together. You've identified some practical strategies to help you regain a sense of control over your academic focus and emotional well-being. These include:
- Focusing on class material during less intense lectures
- Acknowledging and celebrating even the smallest successes
- Using visual cues like sticky notes as reminders
Remember that progress may not always be linear, and it's important to be patient with yourself as you work through these challenges. Celebrate your successes, no matter how small they may seem, and continue building on your progress. You've got this! And don't forget, if you need any further support or guidance along the way, I'm always here to help.
Thanks for summing everything up—it helps to hear it all laid out like that. I’ll keep those points in mind and just take it day by day, ya know?

concern:
So this is a long story and I'm currently in a bit of a unique situation because of which there's no one irl who i can ask for reliable advice so as much as reddit is really not the place to be asking for advice on life changing decisions i've got no other options and here we go.

**TDLR:  was a good student, went to horrible uni and tried to survive. now burnt out, looking to transfer but bc of horrid uni application is fucked. thinking of dropping out want to know abt how likelihood of job opportunities for foreign drop-outs. read passages marked \* for a longer summary**

**\*** The story basically goes that, I am an Indian citizen, but i've lived my whole life abroad so i know as much about India as ur next door neighbour + like 5%, okay. At the end of high school, I blindly trusted my parents' suggestion and got into and started attending a top 10 indian uni which has now become the single worst decision i've ever made in my entire life.

As it turned out, my uni is 100% fucked up. I could go on abt it for days but we don't have time to give a short summary of the vibes: extreme mismanagement of an institution, horrible facilities/classrooms, no sense of academic integrity, poor teaching, no sort of proper functioning basic 'services' like student welfare or career counselors provided, straight up illegal shit like holding classes in a construction site, the fact that you DON'T HAVE WIFI NOR DOES MOBILE DATA WORK BC NETWORK IS SO BAD on campus, the list goes on.

Getting back to my situation, my first year was online and EVERYONE cheated on EVERYTHING but I didn't know how to so I didn't and ended up with the lower side of decent kinda grades (mainly bc most of the syllabus was geared to start off from what was taught in the Indian curriculum that I obv didn't study and so there were large gaps in my knowledge that I wasn't even aware of). For detail, I averaged a 8.33/10 CGPA.

In my 2nd year, we went irl, I got my shit together, worked super hard but bc there is literally no sense of fair grading and cheating is rampant at my uni, so my efforts have only given mediocre results. (I got a 8.73/10 GPA in that sem, now averaging 8.46). This added with overwork (my uni is 6 days a week, 1 month holiday for summer, 1 week for winter, sometimes we do 7 days a week working and the semesters are back-to-back i.e. after the last day of sem 3, the next day is sem 4), I am super burned out rn with v low morale.

**\*** I've decided to transfer but I have a v weak application, I only focused on studying and I do computer science so I need projects/stuff to appear as a suitable candidate. I am generally quiet and mainly focused on self-learning bc of my low-quality classes so my letter of recommendations is also super weak. Ofc i do have potential, i am smart, i am hard working, i am capable. But my situation for the past 2 years has been HORRENDOUS and unfortunately no uni is going to understand that. After all i go to a top10 uni, hundreds of fully capable candidates graduate from there every year and i am the only one making excuses.

**\*** My only other option is to drop out. But my main priority is to leave India bc I cannot live here on my own like i don't know the language or the customs, etc and unlike every other country i've lived in you can't just google get straight forward answers for things in India which is the only survival method i've learnt. Which basically means if I drop out, I would have to learn computer science on my own and get a job abroad and i've never heard of anyone do that or the prospects of that path so I am super unsure.

This post has been an absolute mess but if anyone could help i'd appreciate it so so much.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and support you. Feel free to share anything that's on your mind or any concerns you may have.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’m just really overwhelmed with my uni situation and some big decisions I’ve gotta make, and I’m not sure where to even start unpacking it all.
That sounds really tough, and I'm glad you're reaching out for support. What aspects of university life are causing the most overwhelm for you right now?

Hey, it’s mostly the fact that I feel stuck in a really bad academic environment that’s just draining me. I’m also super stressed about whether to keep pushing through or make a drastic change, and I’m scared I’ll mess up either way.

That sounds incredibly stressful, and it's completely understandable that you're feeling stuck and uncertain. It must be really tough to feel like you're in an environment that's draining you, and also having to worry about making a decision that feels so high-stakes.
Yeah, it’s like I’m caught between a rock and a hard place, you know? I just don’t know if I can keep going like this, but I’m also terrified of what happens if I step away.

It's clear that you're feeling really torn between two difficult options. I wonder, what would your life look like if you stayed in your current academic environment, and how might that compare to the life you'd have if you decided to step away?

Honestly, if I stay, I think I’d just keep feeling more drained and frustrated, like I’m wasting my time in a place that’s not helping me grow. If I step away, I’m worried I’d be throwing away everything I’ve worked for and might struggle to figure out what’s next, especially since I don’t have a solid plan.

It's really brave of you to share these fears and uncertainties. You've clearly been giving this a lot of thought, and it sounds like you're trying to weigh the potential consequences of both paths. I'm curious, what do you think your life would look like in 5 years if you stayed in your current academic environment, and what might it look like if you decided to step away?

Man, if I stay in this environment for another few years, I feel like in 5 years I’d probably just be bitter and burned out, maybe with a degree but no real skills or passion left. If I step away now, I’m not sure, like I could see myself struggling for a bit but maybe finding a path that actually works for me, though I’m scared it could also mean I’m just lost with no degree and no direction.

It's really courageous of you to consider these possibilities, and I can see how both paths carry their own risks and uncertainties. What values or goals do you think are most important to you right now, and how might they help guide your decision-making?

Honestly, I think what matters most to me right now is finding a path where I can actually grow and feel like I’m building something meaningful, not just grinding through for a piece of paper. I also value stability, though, and I’m scared of losing that if I make a risky move, so I’m just torn on how to balance those two things.

It sounds like you're caught between valuing growth and stability, which are both important goals. I'm wondering if there might be a way to find a balance between these two values, or if one feels more urgent right now?

Yeah, I think growth feels a bit more urgent right now because I’m just so stuck and frustrated where I am, like I can’t keep going like this without losing myself. But at the same time, stability is always nagging at me, ‘cause I don’t wanna end up with nothing to show for all this struggle, you know?

I hear how important both growth and stability are to you, and it's understandable that you're feeling torn between them. Let's see if we can brainstorm some ways to address both of these values, even if they don't seem directly aligned at the moment. For example, could there be a way to explore new paths that might offer some growth while still maintaining a certain level of stability? Or perhaps there are small steps you could take to start moving towards growth without completely giving up stability?

Honestly, I’d love to find a way to balance both, but I’m not even sure where to start with that. Like, maybe there’s a way to explore some side projects or online courses for growth while sticking it out at uni for stability, but I’m just so drained already, I don’t know if I can handle more on my plate, you know?

It's clear you're really trying to find a way to honor both of these important values, and that takes a lot of courage. Let's break this down into smaller steps - could we start by exploring one or two small, manageable side projects or courses that might offer some sense of growth without overwhelming you? That way, you can test the waters without feeling like you're taking on too much at once.

Yeah, I think starting small could work, like maybe just one online course or a tiny project that doesn’t take up too much time. I’m just worried I’ll still feel stretched thin, but I guess I won’t know until I try, right?

It sounds like you've made a great start by identifying that growth feels more urgent, but stability is also a priority. By considering small, manageable side projects or online courses, you're taking a brave step towards honoring both of your values. Remember, you don't need to have it all figured out right now. Take it one step at a time, and trust that you can always adjust your approach as you go. Keep in mind that it's okay to feel stretched thin, but you can take breaks when you need to. You've got this, and I'm here to support you every step of the way. Let's schedule a follow-up session to check in on your progress and make any necessary adjustments to your plan.
Thanks, I really appreciate the encouragement and the reminder to take it slow. I’ll give it a shot with something small and see how it feels, and I’m glad we can check in again soon.
